In a referendum held, the majority of the Swiss spoke in favor of Jews being recognized as full citizens of the country.
Referendum on the state monopoly on the production of alcoholic beverages
At the referendum, the majority of the country's citizens supported the introduction of a state monopoly on the production of alcoholic beverages.
Radical liberals staged a bloody coup in Ticino.In the end, federal forces defeated the rebels.The tension in the country has increased, despite the amnesty of the leaders of the movement.
Order must be restored in Ticino
Empress of Austria Elisabeth von Wittelsbach was assassinated by the Italian anarchist Luigi Luceni at the Beau Rivage Hotel in Geneva.
This can be an example for others!

The Zimmerwald Conference of the Socialist International took place on September 4, 1915 and was the first such congress after the outbreak of the First World War (i.e.from August 1914).Although at the previous Congress of the International in Basel inNovember 1912, the war was seen as an opportunity to overthrow the capitalist system, the horrific losses of the belligerents forced the delegates to the Zimmerwald Conference to condemn the war as a product of imperialism and call on the workers to fight against its continuation.The congress was attended by many prominent leaders of the socialist movement: Lazzari and Modigliani from Italy, Lenin, Zinoviev from Russia, the Germans Ledebourg and Hoffmann, the French Bourderon and Merheim, and many others.
Doubtful ideas are spreading more and more
The conference in Kental brought together prominent socialist leaders.Prospects and ways of building a socialist future were discussed.

16 countries have signed the Geneva Convention, which greatly facilitated the fate of soldiers wounded on the battlefield.The modified flag of Switzerland - a red cross on a white background - became the symbol of the new organization.

One of the greatest Russian writers, the founder of the modern literary Russian language, Alexander Sergeevich Pushkin, is the author of such famous works as "Eugene Onegin", "Boris Godunov", "The Captain's Daughter".He died in February 1837 in a duel with the Frenchman Dantes.
Committee for the Independence of Poland
In Paris, the Committee for the Independence of Poland was created, the purpose of which was to fight for the independence of Poland from Russia, Austria-Hungary and Prussia.
So what? Poland still won't appear on the map!

Since 1845, in the house of the socialist-utopian M.V.Butashevich-Petrashevsky's acquaintances gathered to discuss philosophical, literary and socio-political issues.One of the members of the circle was F.M.Dostoevsky.By 1849, the most active part of the Petrashevites began discussing plans to create a secret society with the aim of overthrowing the autocracy and abolishing serfdom.In April 1849, the most active members of the circle were arrested and sentenced to death.At the last moment, the death penalty was replaced by hard labor.
The Hermitage, designed by Leo von Klenze, was opened in St.Petersburg.The residents of Russia have the opportunity to look at a wonderful collection of outstanding works of art.
For the glory of the king!
Production of the opera by M.P.Mussorgsky "Boris Godunov".

On February 8, 1874, after many years of work by M.P.Mussorgsky presented the opera Boris Godunov to the public for the first time.Combining Russian folk music with the ideas of Richard Wagner, M.P.Mussorgsky proved that folk music deserves the right to exist.

In 1880 Fyodor Dostoevsky completed the main work of his life, The Brothers Karamazov.This is one of the most exciting works in the history of all world literature, in which Dostoevsky developed the basic ideas that dominated his work after his break with the socialists.In his memoir, The Diary of a Writer, Dostoevsky rejected criticism of his work from the left, noting that no one on the left exposed Christianity to such derogatory criticism as he did in the chapters "Revolt" and "The Grand Inquisitor." Dostoevsky's works had a tremendous impact on the minds not only in Russia, but also in the West, and not only in a literary sense, but also in a philosophical and religious one.
In 1837, a 26-kilometer railway connected St.Petersburg and Tsarskoe Selo.This was the first railway in Russia.

On February 7, 1855, in Shimoda, Vice Admiral Putyatin signed the first official Russian-Japanese agreement - the Treaty of Friendship, Trade and Borders.TheNorthern Kuriles were declared Russian territory, while Sakhalin remained under joint administration.In addition, Japan opened three ports for merchants from Russia.
The originality of the production of "The Seagull" by A.P.Chekhova proved that the Moscow Art Theater is one of the largest creative centers of the era of not only Russian, but also world art.
Meiningen's troupe is created in Berlin
The theater troupe of the Duchy of Saxe-Meining presented to its repertoire in Berlin.The performance was a great success and became the beginning of a series of tours to various European countries.

In 1874, the son of a cattle dealer, Karl Hagenbeck, performed for the first time in Hamburg with a performance of unusual people.In 1887, Hagenbeck organized the first circus to train animals.And in 1907 he opened a unique zoo in Hamburg.
Now everyone can watch lions, zebras and elephants!
In 1880, the school director Konrad Duden published his complete spelling dictionary of the German language.It has become the most authoritative German spelling dictionary.
Finally, the language is unified too!

In 1903, the Germans received a concession from the Ottoman Empire to build and operate the Baghdad Railway, which will connect Constantinople and Baghdad.This became a sign that relations between Berlin and Istanbul are at a high level.
No, that's none of our business

The fire, which raged for three days, destroyed almost a third of all buildings in the city.After this tragedy, the Hamburg authorities reformed the fire protection system and made changes to the city's development plan.
The ship "Austria" sank off the coast ofNewfoundland.This tragedy claimed the lives of 495 people, mostly immigrants from Europe.

The richest merchants in Hamburg founded a shipping company across the Atlantic.The services of the company were gladly used by those wishing to emigrate to America, which became more and more every year.
Duke Wilhelm of Brunswick-L?neburg had no heirs, so his cousin Ernst August II becomes Duke of Brunswick.Thus, the duchy is part of our kingdom.
We are now part of Hanover
In 1838, 42 ensembles from Rhineland, Baden, Hesse and Franconia gathered in Frankfurt for a three-day Mozart Music Festival.This event was also a demonstration of the political unity of the Germans.
Let them sing - there's nothing to talk about!
Puccini turns American plays into Italian operas
On June 9, 1815, the Duchy of Oldenburg became the Grand Duchy.His Highness Peter II became the first monarch to be officially called the Grand Duke.

German theoretical pedagogue Adolf Disterweg laid down new principles of teaching and upbringing of children.Children had to become conscientious, thinking and responsible citizens of their country.In 1847, the scientist was dismissed from his post for overly active popularization of his ideas.
But these are very interesting thoughts!

In August 1841, Hofmann von Fallersleben wrote the poem "Deutschlandslid".Subsequently, these poems, set to the melody of the Austrian Joseph Haydn "God Save the Kaiser", became the text of the German national anthem.
On June 7, 1840, King Frederick William III dies.His romantic son, Frederick William IV, ascends the throne.
In August 1844, the first zoological garden in Germany was opened in Berlin.Prior to this, zoological gardens existed only in London and Antwerp.
In October 1845, a law was passed in Prussia obliging Jews to serve in the army.
All citizens must serve in the army!
Prussian astronomer Johan Gottlieb Halle discovered the planetNeptune.Until 1930, it was considered the last planet in the solar system.
There are already eight of them!
The premiere of the comedy opera "Windsor Ridiculous", based on the play of the same name by Shakespeare, took place in Berlin.The performance was a stunning success.
And I like the performance more
Krupp is establishing an insurance fund in Essen to insure any of its 970 workers in the event of illness.Insurance is compulsory for every worker.
Following the example of Great Britain, the Prussian government succumbed to the persuasion of some religious and public figures and passed a law strictly limiting working hours for children.
In 1837, the premiere of Albert Lorzing's most famous opera The Tsar and the Carpenter took place in Leipzig.Lorzing is considered the father of German comedy opera.

The chief architect of Saxony, Professor Gottfried Semper, has finished work on the building of the Dresden Opera House, one of his most famous masterpieces.His style combined elements of classicism and renaissance, and in what Dresden is called "Florence on the Elbe", there is no small merit Semper.

Giacomo Puccini, who in 1904 successfully staged an opera based on the American David Belasco's "Madame Butterfly", is preparing to present his new work: an opera based on the plot of "Girls from the Golden West" by the same author.
Enrico Caruso's performance of Rigoletto at London's Covent Garden brought worldwide fame.
Verdi's main work,Nabucco, which premiered at La Scala in Milan, instantly won the hearts of Italians, and one of its excerpts became the unofficial anthem of Italy.

Pope Leo XIII's work "The Rights and Duties of Capital and Workers" began with the words "OnNew Questions." The spirit of socialist revolutions pervaded further and further.The reasons for the conflicts are clear: the rapid development of industry, the changing relationship between employers and workers, the huge incomes of individual citizens amid general poverty, the decline of morality.Socialism threatens the religious and moral foundations of society and seeks to harm the Church and the State, employers and workers, and preaches atheism.To combat socialism, it is necessary to organize societies that promote technological progress and at the same time take care of the weak and disadvantaged.
Labor is as valuable as wealth

Edvard Munch (1863-1944) contributed to the development of Expressionism.His work shocked the upper classes of society so much that some of the paintings were forbidden to be put on public display, because the author depicted the terrible living conditions of ordinary people.

The farmer's son, teacher Ivar Aasen (1863-1896) felt it necessary to reform the writtenNorwegian language, which, in his opinion, took too much from Danish.After several trips to the countryside, Aasen compiled a grammar and vocabulary for the "new"Norwegian language.Although his activities did not contribute to the education of peasants and farmers, many of Aasen's poems became songs and spread to the countryside.Before the death of the scientist, the "new" language received official recognition in theNorwegian parliament.

At the end of the 19th century, the life ofNorway was greatly influenced by the work of Henrik Ibsen, Bj?rnsjerne Bj?rnson, Alexander Kielland and Jonas Lee.Their novels and plays, written in the genre of realism, infuriated members of the upper strata of society, sparked heated debate throughout the country and paved the way for full-scale social reform.

In 1884, Johan Sverdrup, a member of the Liberal faction in parliament, announced the need to form a government based on a parliamentary majority.As a result, this has become a reality, despite the absence of a law or a court decision on this matter.TheNorwegian parliament has become an arena for the struggle of different political parties with each other and with the king.
A place to protect our interests

Inspired by revolutionary sentiments in Europe in 1848, Marcus Tran set out to create trade unions for skilled and unskilled workers.Trade unions advocated the granting of suffrage to all citizens, improved working conditions for hired workers and the abolition of all tariffs on grain imports.The government fought against the activities of trade unions, and as a result, Tran himself was sentenced to 5 years in prison.
Dangerous ideas are spreading more and more

Swedish soprano Jenny Lind was born in Stockholm in 1820.In 1838 she made her debut at the Stockholm theater, and by the mid-1840s she became famous all over the world after a series of successful performances in Europe and the USA.Jenny Lind became the first Swedish superstar, the audience captivated by her wonderful voice and original manner of performance.The singer spent a significant part of the funds received for her performances on charity.

In 1842, compulsory primary education was introduced in Sweden.Although the previous education system was considered quite effective, it was the law on primary school, passed in 1842, that made it possible to almost completely eliminate illiteracy among the population.Local authorities were able to exert pressure even on those parents who did not want to pay due attention to the education of their children.

On December 6, 1830, the first issue of the evening newspaper Aftonbladet was published, edited by Lars Johan Hierta.The newspaper advocated free speech, free trade, lower import duties and democratic reforms.The authorities immediately disliked Aftonbladet: the upper class treated the newspaper with contempt, and the king tried for several years to ban its publication.These attempts were unsuccessful.The newspaper became very popular among the poor Swedes, and the circulation was constantly increasing.The release of the liberal Aftonbladet was the first and most important stage in the struggle for freedom of the press in the country.

1848 was the year of revolutions in Europe.The situation in Sweden also escalated.On May 19, 1848, a large number of dissatisfied and aggressive people of different classes and political views took to the streets of Stockholm.The crowd was very excited, people smashed everything around and beat those they didn’t like.King Oscar I personally addressed the crowd, but this did not help: more and more areas of the city were subjected to destruction.
Goran Frederik Goransson pioneers the Bessemer method

Goran Frederik Goransson was the first to apply the steel production method of the Englishman Henry Bessemer on an industrial scale.Bessemer suggested passing air through molten iron to reduce the carbon level in the metal to an acceptable level.The result was malleable steel.A plant for the production of steel by the Bessemer method was built in Sandviken.
Our scientists contribute to the progress of the country
In the mid-1860s, agriculture could not provide the country with grain.In 1867, the harvest rotted on the vine, and famine began in many parts of the country.

After the poor harvest in 1867, caused by incessant rains, 1868 was also very difficult.The heat and dryness led to the loss of crops, and the famine continued.As a result, many families decided to emigrate from the country.

The difficulties continued in 1869.In the cities epidemics began, and in rural areas, hunger, poverty and despair continued to prevail, and emigrants increased.In total in 1867-69.more than 60 thousand people left Sweden.
In 1871, a solemn ceremony was held in Arvik dedicated to the connection of the railways of Sweden andNorway.
Sale of the island of St.Bartholomew

The small island of St.Bartholomew off the coast of America was ruled by Sweden for 94 years.In 1878, it was decided to sell it to France, as it no longer generated income as a free trade port and became a heavy burden on the country's budget.
We must keep it for the glory of Sweden!

In 1879, Sweden's economy was in decline.The owners of the sawmills in Sundsvall had to cut their wages.In response, they organized a strike, which spread to other enterprises.A total of 6,000 workers went on strike from 21 sawmills.This was the first strike of this magnitude in Sweden.She united the workers of the country and became the first to form the Swedish working class and social democracy in the country, and also contributed to the formation of trade unions.

August Strindberg (1849-1912) is one of the most talented writers in the history of world literature.He wrote plays, novels and short stories, effectively combining naturalism, psychologism and mysticism in his works.The Red Room made Strindberg truly famous.In this book, the author satirically described the state structure and order of Sweden.In addition, the writer is known for his intolerance towards feminists, as well as an interest in the occult.In addition to writing books, he studied photography, drawing and alchemy.

In 1900, the Swedish parliament decided to build an extensive system of fortifications in the Boden area near the Finnish border.This fortress was built on the top of a mountain near the strategically important Lule River.The fortress was supposed to protect the north of the country from a potential threat from Russia.
Yes, we must take care of the country's security!
Book by Karl Jonas Luve Almqvist "You Can"

One of the best Swedish writers, Karl Jonas Luve Almqvist, has made a significant impact on Swedish literature, writing a large number of works that are a mixture of romanticism, mysticism and social awareness.In the book "You Can", he expresses disagreement with the traditional views on marriage and the role of women in society.The book caused a big scandal.

The 1880s saw a decline in agriculture in Sweden.Compounded by rapid population growth and growing discontent, the crisis has led to an increase in the number of emigrants.In the 1880s, more than 340,000 residents of the country left for the United States alone.

The archaic parliamentary system of Sweden allowed representatives of four classes to participate in the work of the legislative body: the aristocracy, the clergy, the burghers and the peasantry.Most of the seats were occupied by representatives of the aristocracy and clergy.Louis de Geer proposed the creation of a bicameral parliament, consisting of representatives of all classes, who would be elected by universal suffrage.After this liberal reform, most of the seats in parliament were taken by representatives of the big bourgeoisie.As a result, a movement began to gain momentum to change this system and give women the right to vote.
No, leave it as it is!
The king of Sweden andNorway, Karl Johan, succumbed to the persuasion of members of parliament and allowedNorwegian ships to sail under the flag ofNorway.

After the Danish victory in the First Schleswig War, in which a large number of volunteers from the Scandinavian countries took part, the Scandinavian movement intensified.The result was the holding of several student conventions, the last of which was held in Uppsala in 1856.
The peoples of Scandinavia must be together!
Bankim Chandra Chatteri publishes Durgesnondini, the first Indian novel.
Indian people can express their opinion too!
Indian Governor-General Lord Dalusi carried out a series of reforms.Despite their unpopularity, they have proven to be very effective.
Our mission in India requires reform!

The treaty formalized the emergence of the state ofNew Zealand, the Maori leaders pledged to recognize the supreme power of the British Queen Victoria, and she guaranteed the preservation of their land holdings, forests and fishing grounds.
Outraged by the attitude of the British, the Maori leader Hone Hecke several times in protest cut down the flagpole with the British flag in Kororarek.
We need to catch this leader!
What can be done to solve the problem?

Every retired soldier who agreed to move toNew Zealand received a free ticket, housing, and a pension on the condition of attending church and church parades, and participating in an annual 12-day militia exercise.

An outspoken critic of the regime, the current head of the Bonapartists received asylum in Switzerland.From there, he calls on our subjects to question our legitimacy.Should Switzerland be required to issue it?
In the Alps, he is not dangerous to us

The Arc de Triomphe, whichNapoleon Bonaparte ordered to build, was inaugurated in 1836 after thirty years of construction.The arch was built following the example of the arches that existed in ancient Rome.The monument depicts scenes from the French Revolution and theNapoleonic Wars.
In 1840, the inauguration of the July Column, built in memory of the 615 victims of the July Revolution of 1830, took place in Paris.
We must remember the fallen heroes!
Charles LouisNapoleon attempted a failed coup at Boulogne.

In December 1840, the body ofNapoleon Bonaparte, who died on Saint Helena in 1821, was delivered to France.Within a few days after the funeral ofNapoleon I, hundreds of thousands of French people came to the cemetery to honor the memory of the emperor.
Frenchman Fran?ois Arban became the first to cross the Alps in a hot air balloon.He started the flight in Marseille and landed in Stupini.

The Belgian musical instrument maker Adolphe Sachs patented what later became known as the saxophone.However, his French rivals initiated a lawsuit that prevented Sachs from making much profit from his invention.

After a failed coup attempt in 1840, LouisNapoleon,Napoleon Bonaparte's nephew, was sentenced to life in prison.He was to spend the rest of his life in the Ham fortress.However, in May 1846, LouisNapoleon was able to escape from prison and move to Great Britain.
As a result of the February Revolution of 1848, King Louis Philippe abdicated the throne.The nephew of EmperorNapoleon I, Charles Louis, was elected president of the republic.
In the course of research at the Paris observatory, physicist Lyon Foucault proved that the Earth revolves on its axis.He then demonstrated his experiment to the public at the Pantheon in Paris.
In July 1851, Proudhon published a book, General Concept of the Revolution in the 19th Century, in which he formulated the foundations of anarchism.
To the surprise of the assembled audience, Henry Gifford made the 27-kilometer flight from Versailles to Trapp in a hot air balloon powered by a small motor.
First flight! What will be next?
On May 15, 1855, the first world exhibition opened in Paris.20,839 exhibitors showcased their products, raffled off 11,073 awards and attracted 4.5 million visitors.

In 1835, Alexis de Tocqueville published his book Democracy in America, which immediately became a classic in both France and the United States.In it, he analyzed the life of Americans and their peculiarities of character, incomprehensible to Europeans.Another outstanding work of de Tocqueville was the book The Old Regime and the French Revolution, published in 1856, three years before the author's death.

The writer Gustave Flaubert was brought to trial after the publication of his book Madame Bovary.The author was accused of gross violation of the norms of morality, etiquette and religious morality.However, Flaubert was acquitted.

In 1894, a French spy discovered a handwritten dossier in the German embassy that contained information about secret French military documents.Suspicion of disclosing state secrets fell on Captain Alfred Dreyfus, a Jew by nationality, and as a result, a military court sentenced him to life imprisonment with a sentence on Devil's Island.Dreyfus's attempts to prove his innocence were unsuccessful.
Let it rot on this island!

In 1896, Colonel Picard uncovered evidence indicating that the author of the dossier found at the German embassy was not Dreyfus, but Major Esterazi.Despite this, the military court acquitted Esterazi.Then Emile Zola wrote an open letter to the President of France, in which he made accusations against the judges, who believed that Major Esterazi had in fact transferred the dossier to the German embassy on orders from the French Ministry of War, the dossier did not contain real facts and was transferred in order to misinform Germans.Later, in 1898, it was revealed that the evidence against Dreyfus had been falsified.

In 1899, when it became clear that the evidence in the Dreyfus case had been falsified, the case was brought to the court of appeal.The appellate court re-found him guilty, refusing to find the charge a miscarriage of justice.This caused a storm of outrage in society, and although Dreyfus was pardoned by the President of France and rehabilitated in 1906, this deed united the left forces in the country and strengthened anti-clericalism and anti-militarism in society.
The eruption of the volcano Montagne Pele on the island of Martinique
On May 7, 1902, the Montagne Pele volcano, considered extinct, erupted on the island of Martinique.As a result, more than 30,000 people died.

Bernardet Soubirua, 14, saw the face of Saint Mary for the first time in a cave near Lourdes, a town in the northern Pyrenees.In 1864, the Catholic Church officially recognized this fact, and Lourdes became a major pilgrimage center.
The owner of the most beautiful voice Sarah Bernhardt will go on a world tour and play the roles of Camilla, Tosca, Adriana Lacouvre and others.Rumor has it that this is her last tour.
Louis Bleriot became the first to fly the English Channel on a monoplane.For this, the London Daily Mail presented Bleriot with a special prize.
Camille Zhenatzi set a new speed record in the Saint-Germain area.His car "Ever dissatisfied" developed a speed of 79.9 kilometers per hour.

Sergei Diaghilev, after moving to Paris, decided to organize a festival of Russian art in the capital of France.In different years, Stravinsky, Tchaikovsky, Rimsky-Korsakov, dancersNezhinsky and Balanchine took part in the "Russian seasons".
The work of this artist marked the transition from realism to impressionism.The painting "Breakfast on the Grass", which depicts a nude woman, caused a scandal at the 1863 exhibition in Paris.

To strengthen the budget, the government in Madrid ordered the sale of some of the church property.In addition, tax breaks for the church were abolished, but the cost of maintaining the property of the church was borne by the secular authorities.

A native of Venezuela, GeneralNarciso Lopez was sentenced to death by the Spanish colonial administration in Cuba.He landed on the coast with a small group of fighters and tried to organize an uprising, after which Cuba would become part of the United States.The plan failed due to the lack of real support from the local population.

To combat the riots provoked by the Cuban rebels, the governor general ordered the resettlement of all citizens living in the countryside to special camps in large cities.In this way, the governor-general hoped to deprive the rebels of sources of food and ammunition, as well as places to hide.
We must restore order in Cuba!
We learned that a significant number of planters in Cuba would like the island to be ours.Perhaps Spain will agree to sell it.
Let's offer them to sell Cuba
North American parties have come up with an offer to buy Cuba from us.
No, Cuba will forever remain our Pearl of the Antilles!
Yes, we can sell the island for a reasonable price
Commission to discuss reforms in Cuba
Will the king agree to convene a commission to discuss the reforms that need to be carried out in Cuba?
Yes, it is worth discussing reform projects
Pablo Picasso abandons traditional views of painting and creates his own style, combining sculpture and African cultural traditions.
Alienation of public lands at the initiative of Mados

In 1855, the Minister of Public Welfare, Pascual Mados, tried to find additional funds to fill the budget and ordered the transfer of all public lands to state ownership.This had a positive effect on the centralization of the country, but farmers and peasants lost the opportunity to use publicly owned land.
To take these lands away - we need money!
We will find another way to fill the budget

After theNapoleonic wars, the national militia, formed from local militias, kept order in the cities.In 1844, the Marquis of Ahumada proposed the creation of aNational Guard Corps, subordinate to the Ministry of War.The guard was supposed to replace the militia.
No, the police are doing their job

The Sultana, the first Omani ship to travel to theNew World, arrived inNew York in 1840.The authorized representative of the Omani Sultan, Sayyid Said ibn Sultan, was on board.He was to meet with members of the US government and discuss prospects for establishing trade ties between the two countries.
Under Sultan Said, Zanzibar became the richest province of the Sultanate.After Said's death in 1856, the sultanate was divided between the ruler of Zanzibar Majid and the ruler of Muscat Tuvaini.

Over the past four years, many Zanzibar residents have come to believe that maintaining their country's dependence on Oman is absurd, since Zanzibar is much richer.Should we declare complete independence from Oman?

Four years after the death of Sultan Said, Majid refused to pay tribute to his brother Tuvaini.With the mediation of Lord Canning, the Viceroy of the King of India, an agreement was reached, providing for the declaration of independence of Zanzibar after the payment of tribute.

The publication in 1885 of Mark Twain's The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn was a milestone in the development of American fiction.Prior to this, American authors wrote in the same literary English as their European counterparts.Mark Twain became the founder of literary American English, incorporating fragments of speech from ordinary Americans into his work.In addition, the author made an attempt to point out the problems that exist in American society, to the fact that every person, regardless of social status and skin color, is capable of actions worthy of respect.At first, the book was criticized, but no attention was paid to the problems raised by the author.
The train, which was powered by the # 999 engine, set a speed record, reaching 112 mph on theNew York Railroad section.

Presidential candidate William Jennings Brian called for as much free silver coin to be minted as possible.For this he was called a populist and a silver republican.His appeal was perceived as a desire to break all contracts and an attempt not to pay creditors.
You shouldn't crucify humanity on a golden cross

The ship "Resolute" was discovered in theNorth Atlantic Ocean.The team left the ship and went in search of Arctic explorer Sir John Franklin.The US bought the ship from those who discovered it, repaired it and returned it to the UK.
Bring it back - right and right
Politician and lawyer Horace Mann began implementing educational reform in Massachusetts.The education system he invented subsequently began to operate throughout the United States.
The US Congress decided to create the Smithsonian Institute, directly subordinate to the president.The goals of the institute were to support scientific research and expeditions, popularize science.
There are many unknowns both on Earth and in heaven ...

In 1841, the first collection of essays by Emerson, a representative of a new, mystical philosophy, formed in theNew World, was published.Although most Europeans do not regard Emerson as a philosopher as such, his influence on European philosophy has been significant.Thus,Nietzsche's philosophy is based on the writings of Emerson.

In 1861, Oliver Wendell Holmes published Common Law, where he outlined the history of the formation of common law.In the book, the author argued that common law does not obey the laws of logic, but is based on the decision of the judge, who is guided by the principle: "The life of law is not logic, but experience." This work instantly became a classic, Holmes himself first became a professor at Harvard, and a year later he was appointed President of the US Supreme Court.The publication of the Common Law was a sign of a growing pragmatism among American intellectuals and heralded the final loss of faith in moral principles.
The law is the will that the sheriff must obey

In 1885, Ulysses Grant published his autobiography, in which he talked about the most interesting events of his life.He began writing this book when he learned that he had throat cancer in order to provide for his family after death.Grant's memoirs became a true masterpiece, readers admired the author's frankness, simplicity of presentation and original style of the book.Mark Twain compared this work with Caesar'sNotes ...The book was a huge success and still remains one of the most published works.This is possibly the best book ever written by an American president.

Alfred Thayer Mahen wrote The Role of Sea Power in History, where he analyzed the significance of the sea power of states throughout the history of mankind.This book became another argument in favor of those who proposed increasing the power of the American fleet and said that the United States has its own interests in all corners of the globe.
Sea power is the key to victory

In an effort to combat anti-war sentiment among conscripts and members of the lower classes, Congress in 1799 passed with some amendments laws on espionage and incitement, which prohibited criticism of the president and state policies during the war and seriously made life difficult for foreigners and people who asked for political asylum.The passage of these laws was supported by several important decisions of the Supreme Court, and the laws have been in force for almost 150 years.
Attacking a country whose citizens are fighting with weapons in their hands is treason
Differences in views are common in a free country

Pinkerton detectives, who have proven they can easily investigate train thefts and catch cheats, have taken up strikes and infiltrated the ranks of well-known secret organizations such as Molly Maguire.
We are always on the alert!

8 teams entered a new well-organized league: Boston Red Caps, Chicago White Stockings, Cincinnati Reds, Hartford Dark Blues, Louisville Grace,New York Mutuals, Philadelphia Athletics and St.Louis Browns.

The fire broke out at the stable of Patrick O'Leary's residence on Dekoven Street and quickly spread throughout the downtown area, destroying 17,450 buildings.In addition, 300 people died and more than 98,000 were left homeless.

In a short skirmish in Tombstone, Arizona, Whitet, Morgan and Virgil Earp, along with Dr.Holliday, killed Billy Clenton, as well as brothers Tom and Bob McLaury, their political opponents, members of the Cowboys group.
The first baseball game took place in theNew York suburb of Cooperstown.TheNew York Knickerbockers lost 1-23 to theNew YorkNine.
Baseball could be the most popular sport in the US!

Francisco Madero issued a statement in which he argued that the results of the recent elections in Mexico were rigged and Porfirio Diaz was illegally occupying the post of president of the country.Madero urged people to take up arms.
Diaz says he will remain in office
Francisco Madero manages to convince Pascual Orozco and Francisco Villa to support him in the fight against Diaz.
Emiliano Zapata led a peasant uprising in the province of Oaxaca.
For satirical cartoons denouncing the power of Jose Posada again ends up in prison.
Dangerous ideas are spreading more and more
The concordat of 1860 improved relations with the church and brought back French priests and teachers of parish schools to the country.
Faustin Soulik, one of the candidates in the 1847 presidential election, declared himself the second emperor of Haiti, Faustin I.
Prominent journalist and Colorado party leader Jos? Battle y Ordones pushed for political reform that enhanced the role of the legislature.
American explorer Hiram Bingham discovered the ruins of the ancient Inca city of Machu Picchu.
Another historical gap has been filled!
Guano agricultural fertilizers are in great demand in Europe andNorth America.The huge amount of guano in our offshore islands can be a major source of income for the country.
Tobacco smoking became more and more fashionable.In 1837, the Vienna authorities banned smoking on the streets and in public places.

At the age of 67, the Austrian emperor Franz I died.His heir was the mentally and physically disabled son Ferdinand I.Actual power in the country was concentrated in the hands of members of the privy council, which included Clemens Wenzel and Prince Metternich.
To make Hungary more independent, Hungarian was declared the only language spoken in the Hungarian Parliament.
Let them speak Hungarian, if they like it so much!

The Serb Ilya Garashanin in his work "Inscription" appeals to all representatives of the South Slavic peoples with an appeal to actively fight the Austrian and Turkish oppressors.This work became a guide to action for the national movements of the Slavic peoples.
Slavs want to be free? Funny!

In 1854, the Bavarian princess Sisi married the Austrian Emperor Franz Joseph I.Her unusual manners, which often did not meet the requirements of etiquette, made her popular among ordinary people.In 1898, the Empress was assassinated in Geneva.

After the famous Viennese architect Joseph Urban joined the Boston Theater Company, the European influence on the architecture of American theater buildings became very noticeable.As a result, wonderful designs have been created.

Our governor in Schleswig proposed to fight against anti-German manifestations in this province.To do this, it is necessary to introduce education in German and expel the Danish citizens who still live there.Should we accept this offer?
In Karlsruhe, the theater of the Grand Duchy burned down to the ground.63 people were killed.

In 1842, in Donostauf near Regensburg, the Valhalla monument was opened, built in the Greek style and named after the famous land of the dead in Scandinavian mythology.Busts of famous Germans were exhibited in the "hall of fame".

The love affair with the dancer Lola Montez led to the end of the reign of King Ludwig I, who granted his mistress the title of count.In conservative Catholic circles, the resistance to this connection of the monarch was so great that the king had to abdicate the throne.Lola Motez herself died inNew York in poverty.
The construction of the new gallery lasted from 1836 to 1853.The exposition is based on the works of old masters.
Composer Richard Wagner completed the construction of the Festspielhaus in Bayreuth.It was decided that a German theater festival would be held here every year.
British monarchy breaks away from the house of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha

Now that the British-German war is going on, our cousins ??in Britain have decided to abandon kinship with us, so as not to spoil their own reputation! They call themselves the "House of the Windsor" and they don't want to do anything with us anymore.
Blood is not thicker than water

During the war between Prussia and Schleswig-Holstein, the Danish king Frederick VII granted a constitution that contained a provision for parliamentary elections and limiting the king's power.Although the king continued to appoint ministers and pass laws, the day of the adoption of the constitution was the birthday of Danish democracy.
In 1871, Louis Pio forms the Danish section of the International and begins campaigning for social reform and workers' unity.

In 1872, after months of a strike, Louis Pio called for a rally in Copenhagen Square.The police agreed to hold the rally and organized heavy patrols to maintain order.A fight broke out and police arrested a number of protesters, including Pio, who received five years in prison.

In 1875, the socialist leader Louis Pio was amnestied on the occasion of the king's birthday.He again led the growing socialist movement.After a series of conflicts with the authorities, he unexpectedly emigrated to America.Subsequently, it became known that the police bribed him.
Give him a bribe and he emigrates
Slave revolt in the West Indies

In 1848, a slave revolt broke out in the Virgin Islands, which belonged to Denmark.Governor Peter von Scholten decided to give them freedom rather than crush the rebellion.He referred to the 1847 law, which stated that the children of slaves are not slaves.This caused a conflict with the planters, the governor was brought to trial, but was acquitted by the Supreme Court.
From 1886 to 1892, about 25 fortifications were built on the island of Zealand to repel a possible German attack.
Von Keller launches Germanisation campaign in northern Schleswig

After the loss of South Jutland, Ernst Matthias von Keller launched a violent campaign to Germanize this former Danish province.Danish citizens were expelled, and an earlier law of 1888 on German as the only language of instruction in public schools began to be strictly enforced.
In 1899, the unions agreed to start a general strike.

P.A.Alberti announced his resignation from the post of Minister of Justice after confessing to embezzlement by his own bank of 15 million kroons, which is a fifth of Denmark's budget.He received several loans using the national treasury, and his arrest led to the resignation of the government.He was convicted along with two ministers who assisted him in covering up the crime.
Sale of Virgin Islands to America
Considering the US request for the sale of the Virgin Islands, an advisory committee decided to sell the islands, which was done in 1917.
In 1882, it was published by A.D.Jorgensen "History".The author called his goal the desire to help the Danish minority in Germany.
The company was founded after the war of 1864, when the country lost a third of its territory.The goal of the company was to develop virgin lands in Jutland and ensure the country's food security.
Christiansborg Castle was rebuilt after a fire in 1794 and burned down again in 1884.The citadel was badly damaged, but the castle was not rebuilt for political reasons until 1907.

In 1892 Carlsberg's owner Carl Jacobsen founded the Carlsberg Glyptotek.At first, the exposition consisted mainly of sculptures from the personal collection of Jacobsen, who was fond of contemporary art, and later, works made in the style of classicism were added.
Estrup, a longtime prime minister, was not a popular figure.In 1885, a young socialist terrorist tried to shoot him, but a bullet hit the button of his coat.
Do you want to kill me?

The corporation was founded by representatives of 11 breweries in Copenhagen in 1891.In 1894, Tuborg joined it; in 1903, close cooperation with Karlsberg began.United Breweries became the largest brewery in Denmark.In 1969 they finally merged with Carlsberg.

Jacob Christian Ellehammer created the first Danish airplane.The flight took place on September 12, 1906.In addition, Ellehammer designed an air-cooled starting engine, a hovercraft, and a helicopter that took off on September 1, 1912.
In 1843, the Danish writer and philosopher Soren Kierkegaard published his book Eli-Or.After the appearance of this work, Kierkegaard began to be considered the founder of existentialism.
On the ruins of Copenhagen's old fortress, Georg Carstensen built the first real amusement park, Tivoli.

The first school for children from poor families was opened.Subsequently, such schools began to appear on large farms.As a result, the level of education in the country has increased significantly over several decades.Boys and girls who had already started working were admitted to schools.

In 1871, Georg Brandes gave the first of a series of lectures on culture.Subsequently, he and his brother Edward became central figures in political and cultural disputes in Denmark.The brothers began publishing the Polittiken newspaper and laid the foundation for liberalism in the country.
Increased interest in politics and awareness was the prologue to the creation of the Liberal Party
America's interest in the Caribbean grew, and some advisers offered to acquire the Dutch West Indies as a strategic base to defend the Caribbean.
Historically, Denmark accepted the US proposal, but it could well have refused either because the price was too low or because of the chauvinistic sentiments prevailing at that time.

In 1838, the most popular Flemish novelist of the 19th century, Henrik Conciens, finished work on one of the masterpieces of world literature - the novel The Flemish Lion.The history of the struggle of the oppressed Flemish people, who defeated the French army in the Battle of the Golden Spurs in 1302, has become a symbol of Flanders.

In 1847, the Flemish living in Belgium adopted a manifesto, which called for the unification of Flemish sports clubs, theaters, scientific organizations, etc.into a wide Flemish movement.At first, the movement was apolitical, but gradually its participants began to pay more and more attention to politics.In the end, within the framework of the movement, political parties were formed that lobbied for the interests of the Flemish population.

The second half of the 1840s was a difficult time for the Belgians, especially for the Flemish population.In 1845, the potato plague killed almost the entire potato crop.As a result, famine began in rural areas of Flanders, people lived in poverty.This difficult period lasted until 1850.
Formation of the Free Trade Association

In 1846, with the potato plague raging and the people living in poverty, the Free Trade Association was organized in Belgium.To provide the population with food, duties on the import of grain were canceled.

Adolphe Sachs was a talented musician and musical instrument maker fromNamur, Belgium.In 1846 he created a new musical instrument, which is now called the saxophone.This instrument became very popular among Parisian musicians, and then conquered theNew World - the saxophone was used by all American jazz groups.

Ernest Solvay (1838-1922) is one of the most talented chemists in history.Now one of the largest in the world and the largest chemical company in Belgium is named after him.In 1862, the scientist invented the ammonia process, which already in 1865 made it possible to begin the industrial production of soda.

In 1865, Father Damian de Wester, a priest from Tienen in Brabant, traveled to the island of Molokai in Hawaii to help the island's leper colony.Damian lived with lepers for 20 years, and he himself died of leprosy in 1889.

In 1836, the Liberals, following the example of the Conservatives who founded the Carleton Club in 1832, founded the Reform Club, which would become the center of liberal ideas in Britain in the decades to come.
Reforms?Not sure if we need them ...
In 1838 in London, Dickens published his novel Oliver Twist.In the work, the author drew public attention to the miserable situation of the workers and their lack of any rights.

Thomas Cook, an English typographer and worldly preacher, organized the first group tour by train from Leicester to Loughborough.Cheap travel packages, including payment for accommodation, food and drinks, have become more affordable for the population
I also want to go on vacation!
On February 10, 1840, Queen Victoria married her cousin, Prince Albert of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha.Unlike many other marriages of the time, this was a love marriage, not a dynastic marriage.
In July 1841, the first issue of the Punch magazine was published.It is the first ever satirical journal published continuously over a long period of time.
We'll keep an eye on them!
George Williams founded the Christian Youth Union in London in 1844.The movement spread throughout the world and was active for many decades.
It's great to participate in it!
The fungus destroyed most of the Irish potato crop.Hunger is inevitable!
I'm afraid there is nothing we can do to help!
Let's see what we can do!
William Makepeace Thackery publishes Vanity Fair in 1847, a book criticizing the lack of spirituality and falsehood of the so-called "high society."
In 1850, the first telegraph line was opened linking Great Britain and mainland Europe.A 25-mile line connected Dover and Calais across the strait.
This will speed up the connection!

In 1851, the World's Fair was held in London, which was attended by 6,039,195 visitors and 13937 exhibits from 15 countries were exhibited.The Crystal Palace, specially built for the fair, has become one of the landmarks of London.
George Bernard Shaw writes The Quintessence of Realism and founds the Independent Theater Society, bringing a new, radical current of realism to English theater.

In 1893, the second collection of poems by William Butler Yeats, Rose, was published.His sense of rhythm and syllable was almost genius.Now Yeats seeks inspiration in Irish themes and begins his long ministry of Irish republicanism mixed with aesthetic mysticism.

Hopkins' works were not published during his lifetime, but after the author's death a collection of his poems was published.Hopkins invented a new rhythm of versification and gave impetus to the development of the modernist movement.Although Hopkins' poetry is considered modernist, at the same time he is considered a religious poet.He converted to the Catholic faith in his youth and was a student and later professor of medieval Christian philosophy.
Will the storm bring you a grain after the crash?
Queen Victoria establishes the America's Cup sailing competition.In the 19th century, teams from the United States won all prizes.
Steamer "Great Britain" I.K.Brunel becomes the first propeller-driven ship to cross the Atlantic.
The 60th anniversary of the reign of Queen Victoria was celebrated on a grand scale.On this day, she first appeared in public after the death of her husband Albert.

Adopted to prevent the influx of imported grain after theNapoleonic Wars, the law made it possible to artificially maintain high incomes for farmers.In 1846, the Conservative government, led by Sir Robert Peel, abolished the Bread Law.This was the beginning of the British free trade policy, which will continue into the 20th century.
We cannot open our market to cheap imported grain!
In 1857, the first mountaineering club was founded in London.

The first football club was founded in Sheffield, so called “FC Sheffield?The purpose of its creation was to eliminate the confusion that has arisen due to the increased popularity of rugby.The rules adopted at Sheffield have become an important part in the development of this sport.

FlorenceNightingale is considered the founder of the modern nursing system.During the Crimean War of 1853-56, she, with 38 assistants, established field service for the wounded in the British army, which sharply reduced the mortality rate in hospitals.In 1860, Florence organized the world's first school of nursing at St.Thomas Hospital (London).She has also worked in health care, medical reform and hospital management.

Representatives of the middle and lower classes, who still did not have voting rights, founded a movement whose goal was to democratize Britain.In their opinion, it could contribute to economic growth and improve the living standards of workers.
Give them something they ask for

Workers on the Tuff Weil Railroad in Wales went on strike in 1901, demanding that the House of Lords bar companies from suing unions and demanding damages caused by the strikes.This decision dealt a serious blow to the trade union movement and gave support to the nascent Labor movement.

In 1882, England and Australia hosted one of the most memorable international competitions in cricket history at London's Oval Stadium.In this three-day competition, the scales tipped one way or the other.The British lacked some seven runs to defeat Australia in the last innings.It was such an exciting match that one of the spectators died of a heart attack, and after it ended, the Sporting Times published the following immortal obituary: “In memory of the dearly beloved English Cricket, who died on the Oval on August 29, 1882, bitterly mourned inconsolable admirers and acquaintances.Rest in peace.The body will be cremated and the ashes sent to Australia."

Scientist Charles Darwin, based on the results of research obtained during the voyage on the ship "Beagle", wrote the work "The Origin of Species", in which he argued that all living organisms evolved as a result of natural selection.His ideas were hotly contested.
Is man descended from a monkey? Funny!

In 1877, Spencer Gore became the first tennis tournament winner held at the English Croquet and Tennis Club in Wimbledon, London.Spectators paid 1 shilling to enter.The final was watched by about 200 spectators.
Jack the Ripper and the poverty of London

The murder of at least six London prostitutes by serial killer Jack the Ripper shocked Victorian society.The excitement and horror at the same time drew public attention to the extreme poverty and debauchery that reigned nearby in the East End, especially in the Whitechapel area, where the murders were committed.While the police unsuccessfully search for the killer, English high society will be preoccupied with the social problems of the lower strata of the population.
Let's focus on the problems of the poor!

Samuel Phelps's production of A MidsummerNight's Dream revived interest in Shakespeare.The simplicity and harmony of the production showed that any good drama can be successful.From that moment on, all theaters began to copy his style.
Charles Latuidge Dodgson, writing under the pen name Lewis Carroll, publishes the first of his two children's books.Illustrations by Sir John Tenniel.
Through the looking glass awaits us ...
Thermopylae's clipper made the passage from Gravesend to Melbourne in a record 63 days.

19 months after construction was completed, a bridge over the Firth of Tay near the city of Dundee collapsed from strong winds.The destruction of the bridge led to the fall of a six-carriage train.Bridge architect Sir Thomas Burch was found guilty and suspended from building a bridge over the Firth of Forth

At the end of May, a race took place between four tea clippers - Firey Cross, Ariel, Taiping and Serika, which simultaneously left Fuchow."Taiping" arrived half an hour earlier than everyone else, for which he received an award - an additional 10 shillings per ton of cargo.

Artist, art theorist, writer and public figure, William Morris broke with the "sad state of decorative arts" in Britain and created a simple yet beautiful style of artistic furniture design.His reclining chair with footrest has become a classic.
Edward Elgar, having created "Enigma Variations", became a famous composer.His symphony brought classical music to life in Britain.

Athletics became more and more popular, and the organization of the first championship was only a matter of time.Unlike gymnastics festivals in Germany, here the success of one athlete was more important than the success of the team.
Is sport really that good for your health?
Prohibition on the purchase of officer ranks

Partly because of the colossal unprofessionalism of officers revealed during the war of 1853-56, and partly because of anti-aristocratic sentiments, the practice of buying officer ranks was abolished in 1871.From that point on, training was required to become an officer.The professionalism of the army grew, but the tendency to make unfounded accusations of incompetence increased, which caused discontent among the officers of the old school.
The current system is quite good

Now, during the war with the Germans, the German origins of our royal house are raising questions from some of our subjects.Some even question the royal family's loyalty to Britain's interests.There was a proposal to change the name of the royal family to demonstrate the crown's absolute loyalty to the interests of Britain.
Long reign to the House of Windsor
Charles Sturt explored the interior of Australia and determined that there were no large lakes or an inland sea.

Desiring to receive the reward promised to whoever crosses Australia from south to north, Robert Burke and William Wills set out on a journey and were able to reach the Gulf of Carpentaria.On the way back, they died in the Cooper Creek area.The group that came out to meet them left Cooper Creek 8 hours before the travelers appeared there, believing that they were missing.

The federal government announced that the ? 200 prize will be split between five citizens who submitted identical designs to theNational Flag Design Competition.More than 32,000 people took part in the competition.
Starting with The Snow River Boy, this writer began to paint enchanting pictures of the underpopulated regions of Australia, and his song "Dancing Matilda" became almost the anthem of the country.
Father Damian and the lepers of Molokai

After Hawaii was opened to the outside world, new terrible diseases appeared on the islands.One of these curses was leprosy.Fear of the disease, which was easily contagious, prompted the authorities to establish a leper colony on the island of Molokai in order to isolate the victims of leprosy there.The Belgian missionary, Father Damian, offered to take over the management of the colony in order to make life easier for the victims of this disease.
Put him in charge of the Molokai colony

In the mid-1830s.A wave of religious fervor swept over the United States.Charismatic preachers appeared who urged believers to return to the true Bible commandments and lead a highly moral life.The emergence of several new Protestant sects has led to controversy over dogmas and rituals and schisms in the traditional churches.All of this increased the influence of Christianity among the lower and middle class of Americans, while religious fervor in Europe faded.

At the beginning of the 19th century, numerous sects emerged within the Protestant branch of Christianity in the United States, and this created an environment for in-depth study of theology.One of the most influential currents that emerged as a result was American Unitarianism.It emphasized the role of reason in understanding theology (and thus the denial of the idea of ??the Holy Trinity), on the innate virtues of humanity and, as a result, on its ability to improve itself.Unitarianism has become widespread among the middle and upper classes in the northeastern United States and has spawned some movements for social progress - from popular education to abolitionism.
Faith and Reason Can Be Reconciled to Improve Humanity

A direct consequence of the religious revival of the early 19th century in the United States was a rapid increase in the number of voluntary associations formed to improve society.These organizations fought to solve social or moral problems of society, helped the disadvantaged and promoted education as a way out of poverty.Historians have dubbed them the "Philanthropic Empire".These associations were involved in creating the social infrastructure of a rapidly growing society, which was changing very quickly under the influence of new economic forces.

Bishop and later Archbishop ofNew York, Hughes worked tirelessly to integrate Catholics, especially newly arrived immigrants, into the fabric of American society.At the same time, he fiercely defended the control of the Catholic hierarchy over the institutions and property of the church.

One of the consequences of the religious revival in the United States of the early 19th century was continuous campaigns against vices.They were led by those who believed that they were doing the will of God, trying to eradicate the sinful behavior of others.The saloons were the favorite targets of such crusaders.Sometimes these fanatics physically attacked the salons and their owners.

Founded in 1816 by African American members of the Methodist congregation in Philadelphia, this church rapidly expanded its followers among free Americans and slaves during the period of religious revival.It became a spiritual outlet for the African American community, as it was completely controlled by it, and a new platform for the struggle against slavery.
Lord our Father, Christ our Redeemer, our man Brother

After the Conservatives won the majority of parliamentary seats in the 1872 elections, serious charges were brought against the party leader, John A.MacDonald.MacDonald was an ardent supporter of the idea of ??building a transcontinental railroad, and liberal leaders argued that the funds for the election campaign of the Conservatives were allocated by the head of the Canadian Pacific, Sir Hugh Allan.MacDonald allegedly promised him a construction contract in return.Despite the fact that MacDonald denied all charges, he had to resign as prime minister.And criticism of MacDonald from another Conservative leader, D.A.Smith, only increased people's distrust of the ruling party.
No, MacDonald must stay at his post!
Louis Riel and the First Mestiz Uprising

Mestizos, descendants of French and Indian marriages, lived in several small communities in the Manitoba area and hoped to gain the right to self-government.Unfortunately, these hopes were not destined to come true.The part of the Hudson Bay coast where the mestizo lived was transferred to Canada without their consent.In protest, the mestizos, led by Louis Riel, rebelled.Louis Riel was a deeply religious person and in his youth he studied at the seminary.He became the leader of the resistance and a true hero for the mestizos.During negotiations with representatives of the Canadian government, Louis demanded guarantees of the rights of local residents in exchange for the consent of the mestizos to enter the Confederation.As a result, the government of Canada accepted Riel's demands, and Manitoba became a Canadian province.
Accept the requirements of the mestizos

Although the Canadian government promised to respect the rights of mestizos, that promise was broken.Petitions of mestizos, who wanted to retain their land allotments after Manitoba became part of Canada, were ignored.In addition, the mestizos really did not like the active settlement of their lands by settlers who came from the west.In early 1885, the situation in Manitoba spiraled out of control and the mestizos took up arms.They passed their own Revolutionary Bill of Rights, announced the establishment of the government of Manitoba, and seceded from Canada.The Canadian army suppressed the uprisings, Louis Riel was captured and, after brutal torture, executed.And mestizos began to be considered full-fledged citizens only a hundred years later.
Is the Dominican Republic part of the United States?
President Baes held talks on the incorporation of the Dominican Republic into the United States.
No, our country will remain independent!
The Dominican Republic is seeking inclusion in the United States.
We have economic interests in this country
Let them join the United States!
Do we want to annex the Dominican Republic?
The representatives of the Dominican Republic want their country to become one of the American states!
We are not interested in this region
Is the Dominican Republic part of France?
President Baez held talks on the incorporation of the Dominican Republic into France.
The Dominican Republic is seeking inclusion in France.
Dominican Republic as part of France?
The representatives of the Dominican Republic want their country to become the territory of France!
This is the original French territory!
Well, why do we need this island?

After ten years of political stability, President Ulisse Uro has been assassinated.It turned out that he was transferring government money to his personal accounts in foreign banks, which caused the country to go bankrupt.
Antonio de Castro Alves publishes his book "The Slave Ship" and soon gets the nickname "The Poet of the Slaves." His work contributed to the abolition of slavery in Brazil.

In 1894 Paulista Charles Miller returned from England, where he was studying.Miller brought with him a brochure with the rules, a kit, two balls and his own experience of playing football invented by the British.The first match in Brazilian history took place in S?o Paulo in 1895.Teams of workers from the gas company and the S?o Paulo train station played.The meeting took place in the Carmo Valley and ended with a 4-2 victory for the train station team.Since then, the popularity of this sport in Brazil has grown to unprecedented heights.
Army officer Francisco Sabino organized an uprising in Bahia.The rebels demanded the abolition of slavery and the redistribution of land ownership.
Attention! You have a chance to practice shooting!

Printed in 1852, Alberdi's book "Fundamentals of the Political Organization of the Argentine Republic" was taken as the basis for writing the new Argentine constitution.In addition, many of the provisions of the US Constitution were included in the new constitution.
His ideas are worthy of recognition

This book was first published in 1845.In the book, using the example of the regime of the dictator Facundo, the local “barbarism?is opposed to the European “civilization?The author comes out with harsh criticism of the dictator himself and the people living under his rule, and depicts a bright future for the country after getting rid of the tyrant and his regime.
Duke Leopold IV is the ruler of all Anhalt!
In 1847, our duke inherited the duchy of Anhalt-Koten, and now, after the death of childless Alexander Charles, he has become the ruler of Anhalt-Bernburg and all Anhalt!

With the help of the struggle in parliament, as well as the general intensification of the class struggle due to the ever-increasing exploitation of the working class by capitalists, the gradual concentration of the means of production in the hands of the minority, the policy of "stick and pistol" pursued by the capitalists, our so-called "democracy" has now turned into a dictatorship the proletariat.
The powers of the president have expanded to such an extent that the screen of democracy is no longer needed.Our country is a presidential dictatorship, and you are the president.Viva el president!

To defend the principles of freedom from democratic interference, plebeian aristocracy and mob rule, a committee of conscientious citizens seized power and turned the country into a minarchist dictatorship.Dictatorship is a temporary measure, they argue.

Electoral rights are being curtailed, the party system is increasingly coming under the control of the government, and just yesterday a law was passed in parliament to expand emergency powers.The trends are clear.The fascist ruling party has transformed our country from a democracy into a fascist dictatorship.

Your Highness, due to the instability in parliament, we see no other way out but to proclaim a return to the principles of absolute monarchy.$COUNTRY_ADJ$ constitution and laws invalidated.Long live the king!

The dictatorship is not what it used to be.Pluralism of opinions and long political reforms are gradually transforming the dictatorship into a democracy.Although this does not mean that the ruling party is giving up power, now the opposition can express its opinion.

Political reforms in recent years have led to the fact that the absolute monarchy in our country is called into question.The king no longer has the right to dictate his terms to the country and must take into account the constitutional limitations of his power.For this reason, our form of government can no longer be called an absolute monarchy.

Large-scale reforms of our party system in recent years have turned our country from an absolute monarchy into a constitutional one.The monarch is now only a symbolic head of state, he is deprived of power over the fate of the country and is forced to take into account the pluralism of opinions and decisions of democratic institutions.

This is $IDEOLOGY$ and they adhere to the following policy:
$PARTY$ will now rule in the $COUNTRY$ power.
Traders are free to conduct business and conclude transactions without any interference from the state.
The state does not interfere in the affairs of production.
In general, this is a free market economy, but the state reserves the right to intervene if it feels a threat to national interests.
The state controls the commanding heights of the economy, but a limited presence of private companies is permitted.
The state makes all decisions on the production and consumption of goods and services.
The church is completely separated from the state, and the question of religion is a personal matter for everyone.
Religion is not a public policy issue, but the government takes into account traditional religious values.
The state religion is actively supported, but other religious beliefs are tolerated.
Church and state are one, and therefore religious minorities are constantly oppressed.
The armed forces are the main state, and the spending on the army and navy is given priority.
The government is an active supporter of the development of the armed forces.
The armed forces are cut off from the state treasury, and the government directs its budget funds to other expenditure items.
The government is hostile to the interests of the armed forces, considering them a threat to public policy.
Only aristocrats and capitalists, chosen by the ruler of the country, can take seats in the Upper House.
Only members of the ruling party with the same ideology can represent it in the Upper House.
Each region of the state nominates two of its representatives to the Upper House.
The composition of the Upper House is determined by the ideological preferences of the population.
Only aristocrats and capitalists can vote.
Only citizens with high incomes (no less than civil servants) can vote, but the rich have two votes to one in the middle classes.
Only the upper and middle classes can vote.
Anyone can vote, but the voice of the rich weighs more.
The winner is the candidate with the majority of votes.
The Jefferson Method is the largest average method used in allocating parliamentary seats.
The percentage of voters won by candidates in an election is equal to the percentage of seats won in parliament.
Public gatherings and meetings are allowed.
Free press allowed, but under state censorship.
A free press is allowed without government interference.
Only state-controlled trade unions are allowed.
Only non-socialist trade unions are allowed.
The government actively discourages other parties from publicly competing for votes.
The ruling party harasses the population, forcing them to vote for it.

The number of constituencies or their boundaries are deliberately changed for electoral purposes, which brings the ruling party more votes.The ruling party can use gerrymandering to force the population to vote for it.
The elections held in the country are open.The ruling party knows who votes how, and therefore can put pressure on voters in order to force them to vote for it.
The choice of a voter is confidential information so that no one can influence him through bribery or threats.As a result, the ruling party cannot influence the choice of the population.
The wages are above the usual level.
There is no working day limitation.
The maximum working day is 14 hours.
The maximum working day is 12 hours.
The maximum working day is 10 hours.
The maximum working day is 8 hours.
Availability of safety rules governing incidents involving physical work.
The presence of a developed system of safety rules.
There is no public health system.
Public health care of an acceptable level.
EaP based on the ruling party
Very low level of health care
