Losses from the supply of the fleet
Changes to your army's military doctrine are found here.New ideas allow you to increase the protection of your troops, the speed of their movement, as well as strengthen the fortifications.
These were the first fortifications to be built using the latest materials and the latest achievements in engineering.This technology allows you to build new types of fortifications.
Echelons were trains provided with the necessary personnel who could quickly load and unload this train, which had a great impact on ensuring the timely movement of military units and cargo.
From that moment on, liaison offices were introduced into the division, which significantly improves interaction between divisions.

The development of weapons and defensive structures made it possible to create closed firing positions, as a result of which artillery was able to conduct effective fire throughout the battlefield.The development of this technology allows you to build a new type of defensive structures.
Artillery units are specially trained to provide direct support to infantry units by conducting barrage fire and fire across the squares.
The creation of headquarters at the level of divisions, regiments and battalions became possible thanks to the increased efficiency of the general staff.Soon, all unit commanders had a headquarters.

As the firepower grew, maneuvering could no longer ensure the safety of the infantry units.And now even the units on the front line are forced to dig in so as not to be destroyed by enemy fire.Soon the entire battlefield is covered by a system of trenches and trenches.This technology allows you to build new types of fortifications.

The use of chemical warfare agents in artillery ammunition made it possible to create vast contaminated zones on the battlefield.The gas attack also impedes the movement of defending troops and negates the benefits of fortifications.
The use of gas masks, as well as the development of instructions for behavior during a gas attack, greatly reduced losses during chemical attacks and reduced their effectiveness.

Further development of defensive structures led to the creation of systems of trenches and trenches, located in two or even three lines and reinforced with long-term defensive structures and machine-gun points.For those who tried to break through such defenses, all this created a real hell, similar to that described by Dante in The Divine Comedy.

A similar tactic is used when the enemy has broken through the front line of defense and his advance has slowed down.By inflicting flank attacks, the defenders repulsed their positions and cut off enemy infantry that had reached the second or third line of trenches.The cut off infantry units did not have the opportunity to call in artillery support and replenish ammunition, so they were easily eliminated.Sometimes a successful counterattack even allowed the enemy to take the starting positions.

The inclusion of artillery batteries in the battalions allowed the commanders of these units to receive the necessary artillery support in a timely manner, which was absolutely necessary both in the offensive and in the defense.
The development of tactics and strategy of combat operations led to the creation of specially trained assault units, designed to create gaps in the enemy's defenses.

The first experiments on the use of tanks were crowned with relative success, the main drawback of these steel monsters was extremely low reliability.But, be that as it may, they worked and could break through virtually any defense.
Gradually, tanks became more and more reliable and began to be used to create gaps in enemy defenses, into which attack aircraft and ordinary infantry penetrated.

After the end of World War I, the great powers had to rethink their war strategies.The cruel lessons learned over the long years of bloody and almost fruitless trench warfare were not in vain.One school of military theory prioritized massive firepower training.The artillery was supposed to crush the enemy and literally punch holes in his positions for the offensive.Another school emphasized the mobility of troops, which had to skillfully maneuver and avoid frontal attacks on fortified enemy positions.
Strategic planning or superiority in firepower

Those armies that preferred firepower also had to decide how to use it.The first way - massive artillery preparation, consisted in creating complex and detailed plans for delivering artillery strikes against pre-planned targets immediately before the main offensive, and the other - in simply collecting as much artillery as possible and shelling the enemy until his defenses falter ...
Combined arms combat or emphasis on mobile connections

Armies that preferred mobility also had to choose its aspect, which would be the main focus.They could fight in large masses of ordinary infantry, not burdened with heavy weapons, or rely on forward detachments, often mechanized, which significantly outnumbered the infantry in speed and quickly found and exploited weaknesses in the enemy's defenses.

This is where the development of the main weapons of your units is located.Improvements in this area will raise the fighting qualities of your divisions to a new level and, in particular, will increase their shooting characteristics.

In the period between the world wars, the armies of many states continued to actively reform.A new divisional structure and specialized troops appeared - from the marines to mountain units.More and more motorized units appeared in the armies.

The huge losses suffered in the First World War and the beginning of motorization were the harbingers of the decline of the cavalry as a traditional branch of the army.The way it was used and its role on the battlefield changed as the truck-mounted infantry moved faster and had more firepower and deployment speed.

Technological advances, in particular motorization, have changed many traditional ideas about war.To a large extent, these changes affected the supply of troops - a key problem in any war.It became possible (and necessary) to create large warehouses to supply troops over a large area.The need to accompany combat units with huge convoys disappeared, since the lack of any type of supply could easily be replenished from the rear warehouse.

Cannons and mortars are your powerful and reliable support.Subsequent improvements will significantly increase the combat qualities of your artillery batteries.Heavy artillery will add efficiency to your troops.

The experience of using tanks in the First World War showed their great potential, but the first tanks could hardly move over rough terrain, and their speed was insufficient.It was with wedges that the long journey of creating real tanks - high-speed and maneuverable - began.

Light tanks were a big step forward in the development of armored forces.Usually machine guns or light weapons were installed on them, so these were the first "real" tanks.They were used to support the infantry, which received much needed mobile fire support with sufficient protection from enemy fire.

Armored vehicles were used where tanks and conventional infantry on trucks were not suitable.Usually attached to cavalry or police units, they were able to move quickly on roads and had good firepower.
To counter aviation, whose role in the war was constantly growing, new means and methods were created.Specialized anti-aircraft artillery was a significant step forward in this area.

The aircraft became more and more perfect, but the development of anti-aircraft artillery also did not stand still.More powerful guns have appeared with an improved guidance system and improved shells.

As the experience of the First World War has shown, the infantry, especially in difficult terrain, needs fire support.Conventional guns were too heavy and cumbersome for these purposes.Artillery pieces of smaller caliber and range were developed, which could be easily transported with the help of horses and cars, and even rolled by hand.They were called mountain guns.

Medium artillery guns were created on the basis of old models, improved taking into account the experience of the First World War.More powerful and mobile, they were part of the staff of the infantry formations.
Heavy long-range guns played a large role on the battlefield.They were deployed far beyond the forward positions to support the infantry in the offensive and defensive.

Military science is about improving your army, taking into account scientific achievements.Statistics, logistics and competent planning are becoming important aspects of the art of war.Further improvements will improve the organization of your units.
The use of the telegraph for command and control of troops and communication between subunits significantly increased the controllability and effectiveness of the armed forces.

Preliminary planning of mobilization, which consisted in the creation of assembly points, routes of movement for all reserve units, as well as a schedule according to which they should receive weapons and equipment and plunge into echelons.

The staffing table regulates the place in the ranks and the combat missions of personnel, which facilitated the deployment of units in battle formations.The mobilization process is also accelerated, because each reservist is already assigned to a particular company.

Statistical calculations, which provided information on the required amount of ammunition to fight a certain enemy unit in a certain area of ??the terrain, significantly increased the effectiveness of combat operations.
Considering factors such as morale, food supply, illness and the number of wounded, it became possible to calculate in advance how effective this unit will be in combat.
Using this scheme, it became possible, by calculating the losses on both sides, to estimate the possible losses in the upcoming battles.
The planning and construction of a peacetime warehouse system greatly facilitated the supply of troops during the war.
Calculating how many supplies and reinforcements a standard unit will need for a given period of time makes it easier to prepare for war.

Naturally, well-organized supply depots are a prerequisite for the normal functioning of your armies, but depots alone are not enough, it is also necessary to organize the uninterrupted delivery of everything you need, from ammunition to toilet paper, to the active army.

The fact that high-ranking officers have connections in political circles and are experts on defense commissions, etc.allowed the army to exert a strong influence on political decisions related to defense and security.

In wartime, the army becomes more and more influential and can seize full control not only over the direct leadership of military operations, but also over the country's economy.This situation can be described as a military dictatorship carried out by the General Staff.

In militarized societies, and in times of war and in others, it is often necessary to create not only local administrations, consisting of both civilian and military, but also administrations consisting of officers.This not only strengthened the control of the military on the ground, but also made the army incomparably more influential than other government structures.

From the moment when an unknown pilot dropped the first grenade on the enemy's head, aviation began to be used as a means of delivering ammunition to enemy positions.Soon, specialized bombers appeared, the effectiveness of which was appreciated and began to be taken into account in tactical and strategic planning.
Improvements in design and new aircraft engines have led to the emergence of new models of bombers with increased flight range, increased bomb load and more reliable protection against enemy fire.

The need to protect the airspace over the troops from enemy aviation arose at the dawn of the air war.The first fighters were intended to fight enemy reconnaissance aircraft and appeared long before specialized bombers.

In the eternal confrontation between the shield and the sword, the strengthening of one side inevitably leads to the strengthening of the other.Specialized fighters developed as quickly as bombers, and in the same directions: new engines, improved designs, aiming systems and weapons.

Soon after the appearance of aviation, the question arose about their combat use.Its first task was reconnaissance, then the aircraft began to be used for bombing and fighting enemy aircraft.There was a need for new ideas regarding the conduct of air warfare.

Over time, intercepting and destroying enemy aircraft with fighters became more and more important.Shortly after the start of the use of fighters, it became clear that they are much better at their tasks when acting in a group, providing mutual support in battle.

Air battles took place more and more often, and it became necessary to change aircraft and crews at front-line airfields in order to reduce wear and tear on equipment and avoid personnel exhaustion.The rotation of forces made it possible to more effectively use the most experienced pilots and achieve air superiority.
This doctrine provided for the concentration of aviation efforts on the bombardment of enemy formations on the front line, as well as close cooperation with the advancing ground forces.

This doctrine provided for the concentration of aviation efforts on the bombing of infrastructure in the combat area....Aviation was supposed to interfere with the supply and movement of troops, reduce the enemy's mobility and, thus, deprive him of the ability to quickly respond to attacks by ground forces.

This doctrine provided for the concentration of aviation efforts on bombing the cities and factories of the enemy in order to deprive him of the ability to produce weapons and supplies, break the spirit of the population and force the government to surrender.
It is the education and leadership skills of your army's officer corps.The better the leadership, the higher the organization and morale of the units.

The further development of military affairs led to a situation where, in order to become an officer, it was not enough to be of a noble origin.It was also necessary to obtain a higher education, the level of which was often in no way inferior to the leading civil universities.This became one of the most important reasons for the increased professionalism of officers.

Previously, all training of troops consisted of drill and drill.But the introduction of field exercises into the training course changed the situation radically.Now the troops were training in the field as if part of them took part in real hostilities.New training methods have seriously increased the combat effectiveness of troops.
The professionalism of the officer corps and the fact that most of the officers belonged to the middle class, and not to the class of petty nobles, allowed them to increase their social status.

The old rules said that an officer who violated an order from a senior in rank was liable to a tribunal.This made him indecisive in making decisions.In this regard, the new charter stated that the officer must adhere to the main idea of ??the order of the superior officer, and the method of execution was left to his discretion.
The use of a more advanced control system allowed the commander to issue orders continuously and accurately.

An officer could temporarily delegate authority to one or several of his subordinates with a precise definition of competence.This meant that he did not have to constantly monitor all the issues, and he could concentrate on the most important ones.

The command post exercises were an important stage in the preparation of the headquarters for war.During these exercises, an imaginary military conflict was played out in which two headquarters acted against each other.During the command post exercises, officers practiced command and control, planning of operations, communications, and operational and tactical skills.
In a situation where the headquarters was developing several alternative plans of action, the commander was able to choose the best one and quickly change the plan of action if necessary.
Combat conditions demanded from the commander the ability to give adequate and timely orders in a stressful situation.Such skills were specially practiced or acquired with experience, if possible.
Training non-commissioned officers in the army
Training non-commissioned officers in the army
Competent non-commissioned officers increase the efficiency of the unit and the level of combat training of soldiers.
Intensive training of non-commissioned officers makes non-commissioned officers trained instructors who are themselves capable of preparing the assigned departments.

The development of various schemes in non-commissioned officer schools makes non-commissioned officers of the division commanders who are able not only to carry out the orders of the officers, but also to take the initiative when necessary.

Adopting naval doctrine is about changing the goals and objectives of your fleet.New ideas in the field of tactics and strategy allow you to increase the indicators of attack and defense of your ships, as well as their speed.
The doctrine of heroism in the war at sea

This doctrine was based on the ideas of Jomini and his follower Mehen.The main idea was that the admiral's personal qualities and the morale of the personnel were the key to victory.Mechen's theory was much more complex and contained modern geopolitical ideas, later reworked by Mackinder.
The doctrine of superiority at sea

In fact, this doctrine was a reworking of von Clausewitz's ideas, adapted for the naval forces, with the addition of new elements developed by Corbett.The main idea was that good organization and training of personnel would be the key to victory over the enemy.

The era ofNelson is over.New ideas came up and our naval strategists split into two groups.Some believe that good organization and training of personnel will be the key to victory over the enemy, others, following Mahen, assign a decisive role to the personal qualities of the admiral and the morale of the personnel.The choice is ours.
Doctrine of building ships of the line
Doctrine of building ships of the line

The essence of this tactic is to fire at enemy ships without being in the zone of action of his guns.This is achieved either by using long-range guns, or by skillful maneuvering, when your ships approach the enemy, strike and retreat beyond the range of his guns.

The essence of the tactics lies in the rapid maneuvering of ships with simultaneous firing, which makes it difficult for the enemy to fire at the ships, and makes it possible to deliver a decisive blow at the most convenient time.
The construction of fairly high-speed ships with a large power reserve made it possible to take active steps to interrupt the enemy's sea communications.
New technologies made it possible to build very fast ships with a small displacement and, as a result, more vulnerable.
The use of this technology made it possible to build ships of the main classes, which are small in size, but carry powerful artillery weapons.
The essence of this doctrine was to use groups of specially equipped ships - raiders for operations on enemy sea lanes.
The essence of this doctrine was to create a fleet capable of operating on the high seas, which implied the construction of large warships and escort ships.
The essence of this doctrine is to concentrate the main efforts on the protection of their territorial waters with the simultaneous action of raiders on enemy communications.
The essence of this strategy is to detect and destroy the enemy's fleet on the high seas at any cost.
Such a strategy does not imply the active participation of the high seas fleet in hostilities, and a general battle at sea is considered only as the last option.

With the advent of modern battleships, built according to the new "only big guns" scheme, many admirals began to present the war at sea as a search for the enemy fleet for the only decisive battle of the main forces.Their strategy was to gather as many battleships as possible into one squadron, detect the main forces of the enemy and resolve the issue of superiority at sea in one battle.The advantage should have been gained by the fleet that outnumbered the enemy in the number and caliber of the main guns.

Although the desire to achieve victory at sea in a general engagement prevailed, in addition to the main caliber of battleships, it was considered useful to use other weapons as well.Ships of other classes were called upon to quickly maneuver and attack the enemy with torpedoes, and small-caliber guns were supposed to prevent such attacks.To win a naval battle, it was necessary to maintain a balance between ships of the main classes and escort ships.

Even after the commissioning of the first aircraft carriers, the main element of the war at sea continued to be considered the battle between large surface ships.The aircraft carriers were not supposed to take an independent part in the battle, their role was limited to aerial reconnaissance and the destruction of damaged enemy ships after the battle.

Initially, the role of submarines was limited to supporting surface ships in battle.Their independent actions were not envisaged.For example, ships could receive an order to attack the enemy, in order to then lure him to pre-occupied positions by submarines for a torpedo attack with a feigned retreat.

Until now, merchant ships during the war moved unaccompanied.It was believed that the best way to protect shipping was to hunt for enemy raiders.However, with the advent of high-speed and numerous raiders and submarines, it became obvious that it was much easier to form caravans of merchant ships and defend with an escort to protect them.

The emergence and spread of ships of new classes (aircraft carriers and submarines) forced the admirals to decide on the choice of the strategy of war at sea.The strategy of the existing fleet attached the main importance to a powerful surface fleet, which has an impact on one fact of its existence, the strategy of strikes against bases assumed the presence and active use of aircraft carriers, and the strategy of interrupting communications provided for active actions of raiders and submarines on the enemy's sea routes.

Throughout the XIX century.the ships have changed beyond recognition.As you develop ship construction technologies, you upgrade your fleet and switch from wooden sailboats to iron steamers and battleships, and then to steel cruisers.
Construction of shipyards of a new type
The mechanization of the process of building ships has significantly reduced the time of their construction.
The corvette is the smallest of the wooden three-masted ships, with only one cannon deck, the main purpose of which was reconnaissance.Corvettes are the eyes and ears of the main forces.
Production of new fishing vessels started.Now it was possible not only to use mechanized nets, but also to sort, clean and pack fish right on board.
In these huge factories, special mobile machines were used, which were used to create steamers.
Transport steamships have replaced clippers.Their traditional sails were replaced by a steam engine, which increased the speed and reliability of these vessels.
The Raiders were converted civilian ships armed with cannons and sometimes torpedoes that outnumbered most warships and were intended to attack enemy sea lanes.
Battleships were steel-armored ships that were faster and more durable than their wooden predecessors, but were much more expensive and smaller.

Monitors were the next step in military shipbuilding after battleships.These were low-sided ships, as a result of which it was more difficult to get into them, faster, heavily armed and better protected than the first battleships.
Torpedo boats are cheap, allowing them to be built in large numbers, and torpedo armament gives boats the ability to attack warships of all classes, including cruisers and battleships.
The cruisers inherited the functions of wooden battleships in naval warfare.Yielding to battleships in thickness of armor and power of weapons, the cruisers significantly surpassed them in speed.

The main purpose of the destroyers is to fight against boats and small-tonnage ships of the enemy.The destroyers are equipped with several small-caliber gun turrets, which allows them to conduct defensive fire against small-tonnage ships.
Submarines are equipped with torpedo-cannon armament and are capable of moving under water, although they must still rise to the surface to conduct combat.
Dodreadnoughts are large ships whose armor can withstand multiple hits.They are armed with large caliber guns.
Dreadnoughts are the most advanced warships of the early 20th century, armed with large-caliber guns, which makes them the main striking force of the fleet.
Light cruisers are cruisers with additional weapons.They are not as well armored as battleships and therefore outnumber them in speed.

Even after the advent of the dreadnoughts, there remained a significant interest in ships that would be able to combine the firepower of the dreadnought's main battery and the speed of a cruiser.The battlecruisers were born.They could conduct reconnaissance for the main forces of the fleet and were able to cope one-on-one with any ship except a battleship.Insufficient booking was their main weak point.
Throughout the 1920s.submarine designs continued to improve.Submarines could spend more and more time at sea and intercept enemy wars and merchant ships far from their bases.

Submarines have become a serious threat to surface ships and merchant ships, and the role of the main means of dealing with them fell to the lot of destroyers, who previously protected large ships from surface torpedo attacks.After the First World War, changes were made to the design and equipment of destroyers that allowed them to successfully find and sink submarines (for example, sonar).

Before World War II, the size of destroyers increased, and their tasks were also expanded, to which was added the fight against more and more dangerous aircraft with the help of anti-aircraft guns and machine guns.

By the beginning of the 20s.In the twentieth century, there were two main types of cruisers: light cruisers, usually equipped with 6-inch main battery guns, and heavy cruisers with 8-inch armament.They performed tasks such as supporting the main forces of the fleet together with destroyers, protecting trade routes and raiding.
A further improvement in the design of cruisers in the interwar period consisted in strengthening the reservation and increasing the number of guns, both main caliber and anti-aircraft guns.

Immediately after the end of the First World War, many unfinished battle cruisers were sold for scrap or converted into aircraft carrier cruisers.The rest were equipped with improved main caliber artillery and armor protection.

The experience of the First World War made it possible to make some improvements in the design of battleships: more effective booking for protection against external fire, improved anti-torpedo protection, a widespread transition to diesel engines and further improvements in weapons and fire control systems.The number of new battleships built in the early years after World War was small due to economic difficulties and restrictions on naval treaties, but many of the old battleships were rebuilt in accordance with new requirements and capabilities.
In the 1930s, battleships of a new generation were created.They had more powerful weapons, especially anti-aircraft weapons, as well as improved body armor protection and high speed (about 28 knots).

The first experiments in the use of sea-based aircraft were usually limited to the construction of small runways on existing ships.They showed the fundamental possibility of aircraft taking off and landing on the deck, and the navies of different countries began to re-equip small ships for aircraft carriers.They worked out the methods and tactics of the combat use of aircraft carriers, but these ships were too small to have a decisive influence on the course of the war at sea.

The next step in the construction of aircraft carriers was the use of the hulls of large ships (battleships and battle cruisers).Such aircraft carriers carried many more aircraft and were the first ships of this class that could conduct truly independent operations.However, their capabilities were still limited by design features.

The experience of creating early aircraft carriers forced the navies of major powers to start developing and building aircraft carriers from scratch.This approach opened the way for the implementation of various improvements: an increase in capacity, armoring of the runway deck, the installation of anti-aircraft weapons and new measures to combat the survivability of the ship.It was these new ships that ultimately proved the critical importance of aircraft carriers in the war at sea.
The lessons of submarine warfare during the First World War were taken into account in the design of submarines in the 1920s and 1930s.Submarines have become even more formidable weapons.

Interest in battle cruisers briefly revived in the 1930s, when some naval powers built new ships of this type, designed for raiding trade routes or hunting enemy cruisers.These ships received improved protection without losing speed.They became the forerunners of the fast battleships.

Marine engineering technologies improve the armament and equipment of ships.Over time, your admirals will receive many great toys such as armor-piercing shells, mines and carrier-based reconnaissance aircraft.
Optical rangefinders made it possible to accurately determine the distance to the enemy ship, which significantly increased the effectiveness and accuracy of fire.
This invention simplified aiming and firing, as well as increased rate of fire and accuracy.
This invention of saddle torpedoes is a very effective weapon, increasing their reliability.Torpedoes equipped with such a device deviated much less often when moving in the water column.

The development of mine weapons led to the creation of special types of ships: minelayers and minesweepers, capable, respectively, of installing and removing minefields.Sea mines not only reduced room for maneuver, but could also be a deadly weapon, especially at night or in bad weather.

The new torpedoes allowed the ships to fire a salvo and leave, while the torpedo moved independently towards the target.However, aiming could only be done at the moment of firing, so it was not very easy to hit the target with a torpedo.

Armor-piercing shells were specially designed to penetrate the heavy armor of large warships.The creation of this type of ammunition was a response to the ever increasing thickness of armor plates installed on ships.

Armor-piercing shells were specially designed to penetrate the heavy armor of large warships.The creation of this type of ammunition was a response to the ever increasing thickness of armor plates installed on ships.
The installation of artillery pieces in armored towers significantly improved the survivability of ships.
Mortars fired along a hinged trajectory at an angle of more than 45 degrees.The shells used in these cannons had to pierce the deck, which was usually not as heavily armored as the side of the ship.
The shells fired from the rifled barrel rotated around their axis, which made it possible to increase the firing range and improve accuracy.

Small-caliber rapid-fire guns were designed to repel torpedo attacks carried out by boats and other small ships.But the rate of fire of such guns was so high that the same principles were applied when creating guns of a larger caliber.
The gun turret was a closed rotating armored structure with several guns installed in it.The use of armored gun turrets increased the survivability of ships.
The new large-caliber guns possessed such monstrous power that they pierced the armor of any ship except for huge battleships.

Small spotter planes took off from large ships and carried out aerial reconnaissance and fire adjustments.Later, machine guns and bombs were installed on them, which ultimately led to the fact that these aircraft became, in fact, dive bombers.
The use of a hydraulic drive in naval guns made it possible to speed up targeting.In addition, hydraulics were also used to load the guns.

The installation of additional armor plates not only increased the survivability of the ship, but also provided additional protection against new types of ammunition, including armor-piercing shells and torpedoes.
The increase in size allows the ship to take on board larger caliber guns and more powerful mechanisms without losing stability.More powerful engines compensate for the increased weight of the ship.

At the beginning of the twentieth century, radio communication became an important innovation in the navy.Naval headquarters were able to maintain contact with formations at sea and give them orders, and admirals were able to control individual ships in their squadrons much more efficiently.However, radio communication had one, but a significant drawback: the enemy could also overhear radio messages.Soon all the large fleets acquired radio interception services.
The increase in the main caliber and, accordingly, in the range of the guns of large ships made it necessary to develop observation systems and measure distances for adjusting fire.

In most cases, the first dreadnoughts were armed with 12 "and 13.5" main guns, but this soon proved to be insufficient.New battleships with a large displacement received 15-inch and 16-inch guns, which were much more powerful and longer-range than their predecessors.

Naval science allows you to modernize the fleet with the help of scientific advances.Statistics, logistics and advance planning are becoming an integral part of the creation of a fleet.New improvements will increase the organization of your fleet.
Large-scale night exercises allow naval units to improve their skills in difficult conditions and improve the training of commanders for operations at night and in fog conditions.

Financial institutions are organizations that regulate the movement of money in a country.They go a long way of development: from the formation of the first private banks to the creation of the Banking Supervision Council.
The introduction of a variety of financial instruments meant not only easier capital flows, but also higher income for the middle class from private investment.
The creation of insurance companies made the business easier and safer.Families have also benefited from innovations such as home insurance, etc.
Regulation of buying and selling shares
This not only made it safer, but also made the sale and purchase of shares cheaper in the long term, since now these procedures have become clearly regulated.

This meant that the bankrupt firm had to sell its assets to pay off its creditors.It was a complex but important set of laws that was the first step towards stabilizing the legal mechanism of bankruptcy.
The behavior of the market indicated that the demand for capital was growing, which meant the need to create a capital market.

As the path from resource extraction to production of the final product became longer, channels of specialization were opened in the form of companies distributing products to retail outlets.This made the supply more efficient.
The business begins to improve production efficiency by investing in the development of new capital goods and products.
The business begins to improve production efficiency by investing in new factories and purchasing small component suppliers.

The creation of a special body to oversee the activities of private banks provided the government with the ability to prevent bank bankruptcy or fraud.
The creation of a dedicated body to monitor market behavior provided the government with the ability to prevent firms from going bankrupt or fraudulent.

Since the beginning of the twentieth century, more and more people began to invest in securities.The practice of buying on margin appeared, which made it possible to acquire significant volumes of securities by investing relatively small initial funds.If investments are profitable, then it allows you to cover the cost of raising funds.The risk is that if an investor suffers a loss, then he has to cover the difference between the initial investment and the commission for the purchase of large volumes of securities.A low initial investment threshold allows more people to participate in the stock market game, but increases the risk of bankruptcy for investors with limited funds.

A functioning economy needs a well-functioning monetary system.In order for transactions to be completed without interruptions, the required amount of money must be available.In addition, monetary policy acts as an effective regulator of the economy.

The currency system is based on silver.The issue of money becomes cheaper for the government, which helps to prevent a shortage of money.The problem was that prices pegged to silver dominated prices pegged to gold, which negatively affected foreign trade.

After the abolition of the non-standardized currency (guinea, shillings, etc.) and the introduction of a decimal system similar to the American one (1 dollar = 100 cents), the day-to-day use of money became easier.

The currency system is based on silver and gold at the same time.This created the conditions for the government to issue cheap money at any time, but the difference in price changes created difficulties for citizens.
A system for comparing prices in different currencies and a simplified system for buying and selling currencies have increased the possibilities of foreign trade.

The currency system is based on gold.The issue becomes more expensive for the government, as a result of which the money supply in the country decreases.But it will also stabilize the currency due to the high confidence in gold.
A system for comparing prices in different currencies and a simplified system for buying and selling currencies have increased the possibilities of foreign trade.

By regulating the government bond system, the government could issue loans domestically and exercise control over cash flows.This was an important measure to ensure the stability of the monetary system.
Interest rates as a means of fighting inflation
By allowing the Central Bank to change interest rates, the government could, to some extent, create a balance between inflation and unemployment.

Social and economic tensions within the belligerent industrial powers led to huge budget deficits, and a quick return to the gold standard proved impossible for them.The burden on the budget as a result of social obligations to war veterans, and for the losers also financial obligations to the winners, became unbearable and forced to take the path of increasing the amount of money in circulation.This money was not backed by anything, and the value of the currencies of these countries relative to other currencies and gold plummeted downward.This policy had a heavy impact on the position of those strata of society that had limited or fixed income or investments in rapidly depreciating currency.Many of the governments affected by such actions have become adherents of ideologies,

The development of economic theory has had a great impact on the functioning of the world economy, both at the micro and macro levels.New ideas and theories were immediately adopted by entrepreneurs and the state in order to increase the efficiency of economic activity.

John Elliot Cairns was a follower of John Stuart Mill.His book The Power of Slavery (1862) contained ideas supporting theNorth in the American Civil War, which made a huge impression on the British.Cairns wrote about non-competitive groups in the labor market and was known for his distrust of mathematical economics.Among his works are "The Character and Logical Method of Political Economy" (1857) and "ANew Explanation of Several Principles of Political Economy" (1874).

Robert Torrance was a British Army officer and owned the influential Globe newspaper.Robert Torrance, independently of Ricardo, discovered the principle of "comparative advantage" in international trade (although he promoted the idea of ??"reciprocal tariffs" rather than "unilateral free trade").Robert Torrens also, together with Ricardo, discovered the theory of "differential rent", although in later editions he renounced the Malthusian doctrine of population restriction, on which the theory was based.Torrance remained a consistent critic of the "labor theory of value."

A prolific Scottish journalist, one of the staunch followers of the classical school of Ricardo.John Ramsay McCulloch began his career as editor of the Scotsman, and later worked for the liberal Edinburgh Review, where he served as editor of the economics department until the late 1830s.John Ramsay McCulloch used his position to popularize classical theories and advocated economic actions such as repealing the grain trade law, continuing the laws on the poor, and legalizing trade unions.John Ramsay McCulloch also lectured on political economy at University College London from 1828 to 1832.In 1838 he was appointed auditor of the office for the publication of official documents.McCuloch's main work Principles (1825) was probably the first "serious" textbook on economics (a fairly loyal version of Ricardo's theory).However, it is believed that McCulloch did not make a significant contribution to the development of economic theory.His main contribution was the ill-fated theory of the wage bill (1824), (1825), (1826).He also edited Adam Smith's Wealth ofNations (1828) and David Ricardo's (1846).McCulloch compiled several economic reports fully endorsing Ricardo's theory.His monumental work of 1837 proved the failure of the Malthusian theory of population restriction.He also edited Adam Smith's Wealth ofNations (1828) and David Ricardo's (1846).McCulloch compiled several economic reports fully endorsing Ricardo's theory.His monumental work of 1837 proved the failure of the Malthusian theory of population restriction.He also edited Adam Smith's Wealth ofNations (1828) and David Ricardo's (1846).McCulloch compiled several economic reports fully endorsing Ricardo's theory.His monumental work of 1837 proved the failure of the Malthusian theory of population restriction.

The economist's works have been printed and distributed in your country.After scientists discuss and highlight all the advantages, they will become known to the general population.This will have an impact on the economic processes in the country.

James Mill is a radical thinker who has worked in the shadow of the brilliant Jeremy Bentham.Together they can be called the founders of utilitarianism.Their ideas were expressed in the works of Mill "Elements of Political Economy" (1821), "Analysis of the Phenomenon of Human Reason" (1829).

John Stuart Mill, son of James Mill, one of the most famous utilitarians, quickly became known as one of the brilliant and at the same time the most radical minds in Great Britain.He published several books, including A System of Logic (1843), Principles of Political Economy (1848), Essays on Freedom (1859), Reflections on Representative (1861) and Utilitarianism (1861), which made him central figure in the teachings of social liberalism and a more humane view of society.

Proudhon was apprenticed to a typographer and became interested in politics when he published Charles Fourier'sNew Economic Societal World.Proudhon began writing and in 1843 published What is Property? In the book, Proudhon criticized the injustice of inequality and even coined the term "property is theft." Proudhon's main work, The System of Economic Contradictions or the Philosophy of Poverty, was published in 1846.Karl Marx argued with Proudhon in his book The Poverty of Philosophy (1847).This was the beginning of an ideological struggle between two thinkers.Proudhon contrasted himself with the authoritarianism of Marx, and his influence was especially noticeable among the representatives of the socialist movement of freedom fighters.

Initially, Karl Marx was a Hegelian, but later he significantly changed the idealistic theory of his teacher.Later in Paris, for the first time in his life, Marx encountered representatives of the working class.Marx was struck by their poverty and camaraderie.In an article he wrote for the Franco-German annals, Marx applied Hegel's dialectic to what he observed in Paris.Marx, who called himself a communist, believed that the working class (proletariat) would become the liberator of society.The most significant works of Marx are "German Ideology", "Manifesto of the Communist Party", "Principles of Communism" and "Capital".He lived most of his life in England, where he published his works and where he became the most influential socialist in history.

In his youth, Engels went to Manchester to help his father in a cotton factory.Engels was shocked by the poverty that reigned in the city, and he soon wrote an article that was published under the title "The Condition of the Working Class in England" (1844).He met with Marx, and together they tried to create an international workers' organization throughout their lives.Engels was inferior to Marx intellectually, but he took over the financing entirely.Therefore, without Engels there would be no Marx - and vice versa.

Eduard Bernstein, originally a faithful follower of Marx and a member of the Social Democratic Party of Germany, during his exile in London, changed his views and came to the conclusion that socialism in an industrial country can be achieved only through the activities of trade unions and parliament.He published a number of works in which he challenged some of Marx's predictions about the development of capitalism.He pointed out that the incomes of the proletariat had grown, and that the polarization of the working class and the capitalist class had not yet materialized, and capital had not been concentrated in the hands of a few capitalists.Bernstein's revisionist views were most evident in his book Problems of Socialism and the Tasks of Social Democracy (1899).

While studying at the university, Webb became interested in socialist ideas and in 1885 he joined the British "Fabian Society".The organization believed that capitalism created an unjust and ineffective society.The members of the organization considered it their main goal to reform society in accordance with high moral principles.The Fabian Society has researched and published many brochures on social issues of all kinds.Many of them were written by Webb, including Facts for the Socialists (1887), Facts for Londoners (1888) and The Eight Hour Day (1891).Together with J.Shaw, he wrote the "Plan of the pre-election campaign of the Labor Party." Subsequently, Webb became a well-known figure in social democratic circles and the international trade union movement.

Karl Kautsky was a member of the Social Democratic Party (SDP) and was responsible for the development of the Erfurt Program, which was to transform the SDP into a Marxist party.He wrote and published The Economic Doctrine of Karl Marx (1887) and Thomas More and His Utopia (1888).He broke off relations with Bernstein, whom he considered to have departed from the real revolutionary ideas of socialism.

Jaur?s was elected to the Chamber of Deputies in 1885.Defeated in the 1889 elections, he returned to the University of Toulouse.His views became more radical, and he became an active defender of socialism.But he was not a revolutionary and supported independent socialists.After his defeat in the elections, he finished his large-scale work "The Socialist History of the Great French Revolution." Together with Aristide Briand and Ren? Vivani, in 1904 he founded the left-wing newspaper L'Humanite.At the beginning of the century, the new Socialist Party under the leadership of Jaur?s grew rapidly, but split over the issue of German militarism.Jaur?s defended the policy of international arbitration, while others supported the Entente's actions.

Friedrich List was a nationalist and utopian economist and the founder of the German school of history.His most famous work, TheNational System of Political Economy (1841), opposed the free trade theories that prevailed in the classical schools.However, he was not an ardent advocate of protectionism.List challenged it based on his own observations and analysis and emphasizing political factors, especially the role of the nation in the economy.List believed that the promotion of the productive forces is the responsibility of the state and only after that free trade can emerge, which can be seen as an argument for protectionism.Subsequently, he developed the idea of ??economic "stages", which formed the basis of the German historical school.

Wilhelm Roscher, as a professor at the University of Leipzig (1848-94), founded the German historical school of economics, rejecting the classical principles of non-interference of the state in the economy.Roscher's writings emphasized the evolutionary nature of the development of capitalism, based on the historical analysis of ancient states.His Principles of theNational Economy (1854?4) was one of the most influential works of the second half of the 19th century.Another significant work is the History of theNational Economy of Germany (1874).

Bruno Hildebrand relentlessly criticized Ricardo's classical theories as materialistic and cosmopolitan.Only later did he develop his own ideas, in particular developing the economic theory of "stages".However, he himself did not use these ideas from his empirical and statistical work.

His linear theories used the principles of "moral progress", which would render many theories obsolete.However, his work from 1873 contained almost no historical methods.For his political views, he was forced to leave for temporary exile in 1848.Among his works are "Political Economy from the Point of View of Historical Methods" (1853) and "Money and Credit" (1873).

His oppositional views to neoclassical theories led von Schmoller to enter into a famous controversy with Karl Menger.Although many believe that he lost the argument because he practically did not participate in it (it was reported that after receiving the materials of Menger's thoughts, von Schmoller simply sent them back without reading, saying that they were not worth his attention), von Schmoller retained his influence in German universities, and classical and neoclassical theories were not taught in Germany.Von Schmoller became the owner of the reputation of being the only opponent of the Austrian Menger school.Von Schmoller's political activities are also significant: in 1872 he created the Society for Social Policy, an organization of conservative economists who support the idea of ??the state-industry-labor connection.

Although Wagner was considered an associate of von Schmoller, he actually supported Menger.He became famous for his work on public finance.Wagner was a like-minded person of Lasalle and Robertus, although he did not fully share their socialist ideas, having more conservative views in politics.Wagner was a supporter of easing working conditions and did not consider uncontrolled capitalism to be correct.Among his works is “Financial Science.Volume 1-4 "(1877-1901) and" Fundamentals of Political Economy "(1876).

Cunningham was an opponent of the nascent neoclassical theory, supporting his colleague Alfred Marshall.In economics, he was looking for a way to promote the historical method, which made him one of the leading defenders of the English school of history.Despite Cunningham's unrelenting criticism, Marshall refused to include in their collaborations the idea that the validity of economic laws is determined by historical, social, and cultural factors.Cunningham's rejection of neoclassicism was his entire policy.He zealously opposed utilitarian philosophy and laissez-faire and wrote several works promoting trade unions and protectionism.He also revived interest in the old mercantilist teaching.

Johann Heinrich von Th?nen - owned land in the northern German region of Mecklenburg.Educated in G?ttingen, he spent most of his life on his Tell estate.In his first work The Isolated State (1826), he gave an interpretation of spatial economics, combining it with the theory of rent.His second volume (1850) developed the marginal productivity theory of income distribution and made his author a well-known proto-marginalist of his day.Before his death, he asked to engrave on his monument the equation of the marginal product of labor and wages.

Joseph Schumpeter spoke of Walras as "the greatest economist." Walras was one of the three leaders of the "marginalist revolution." His work, The Principles of Pure Political Economy or The Theory of Social Wealth, was published in 1874, 3 years later than William Stanley Jevons and Karl Menger.However, among the three revolutionaries, it was Walras who set forth a new "marginalist" or "neoclassical" theory in accordance with the general economic equilibrium model.He supplemented it with ideas about the multiplicity of the market and mathematical calculations, which Menger and Jevons refrained from.Walras is rightfully considered the founder of the general economic equilibrium model.

Stanley Jevons' contributions to economics cannot be overemphasized.His authority as the founder of neoclassical theory is unshakable.However, he lacked fame.Jevons could develop his ideas of pure exchange into a large-scale theory, integrating production, capital, money, and the industrial cycle, which would knock Ricardo's theory off the stage.If not for his early death, perhaps he would have achieved this, but his scientific work, on which he worked and which was published after his death in 1905, did not set such ambitious goals.By the time of his death, the "marginalist revolution" was only in its infancy.It was more of an experimental theory, a scientific hypothesis, than a stable, elaborate doctrine.It should be noted that Jevons did as much for logic as he did for economics, achieving outstanding results in this area as well.

Karl Menger is considered one of the three leaders of the "marginalist revolution", along with William Stanley Jevons and Leon Walras.However, Menger's Principles, published in 1871, do not contain mathematical calculations to complement the work of the other two revolutionaries.On this basis, many economists believe that Menger should be considered separately.This can be assessed in different ways.Unlike Jevons and Walras, Menger founded a large school that more or less retained its identity, namely the Austrian school.His two followers Eugene von Boehm-Bawerk and Friedrich von Wieser made a great contribution to the development of this school.

Thorstein Veblen in economics is Jonathan Swift in English literature, a master of satire.The ideas contained in a satirical work should sound ambiguous, so that the reader does not understand if the author is serious, or is just playing the reader.Swift's "Gulliver" is based on this principle, as well as "The Leisure Class Theory" (1899), "The Instinct of Craftsmanship and the Level of Development of Production Technology" (1914), "Imperialist Germany and the Industrial Revolution" (1915), "Higher Education in America" (1918), Absent Property (1923) and many other works by Veblen.Veblen used this principle in all of his works, except for The Theory of Business Entrepreneurship (1904), which looks more like a regular academic work.In any of his work, you can find an idea, that life in a modern industrial society consists of a conflict between "financiers" and "entrepreneurs", between "entrepreneurship" and "industry", between "marketability" and "usability", in general, between capital and production.There is a class struggle, but not between the proletariat and the bourgeoisie, but between businessmen and engineers.Economic thinking brings together bankers, lawyers, brokers and managers, and, in contrast, technical thinking brings together workers and engineers and technicians who lead them.

Alfred Marshall was the first and foremost brilliant theorist who believed that economics should contribute to the well-being of society and that economics students should know about economics and social factors of the modern world as well as about theoretical approaches with which one can understand economics....Many concepts became known to us thanks to Marshall.Partial sustainability analysis, supply and demand curves, the concept of elasticity, consumer and production surplus value, time sharing in the market, short and long cycles - all this was described in the famous "Principles" of Marshall, published in 1890 and reprinted eight times only during the life of the author.

The French philosopher, mathematician and economist Augustin Cournot was rightfully called one of the greatest proto-marginalists.The unique thoughts contained in The Study of the Mathematical Principles of the Theory of Wealth (1838) were unparalleled.Although he was not recognized during his lifetime, his contribution to the modern economy cannot be overestimated.

Jules Dupuis was perhaps the most famous French engineer and economist.Educated at the Paris College of Bridges and Roads, Dupuis had a distinguished career as a civil engineer.His professional career in infrastructure development inspired him to study economics.

The Italian economist Vilfredo Pareto was one of the leaders of the Lausanne school and an outstanding representative of the “second generation?of the “neoclassical revolution?Although his ideas were not very popular during his lifetime, the theory of "tastes and obstacles" was resurrected during the "Pareto Renaissance" in the 1930s and since then has determined much in the development of the economy.

Swedish economist whose work led to the spread of the term "natural" in relation to the long-term equilibrium interest rate.Wicksell's ideas had a major impact on economist James M.Buchanan.Buchanan's public choice theory was a natural extension of Wicksell's assertion that economists should stop acting as if the government were a benevolent despot.Wicksell was a Malthusian and a proponent of birth control.He spoke frequently on moral issues.His most famous work is "Income and Prices", in which he outlined his thoughts on the quantitative theory of money.His views were different from the usual, he considered the indirect effect of the influence of the money supply on pricing.Wicksell also developed the marginal productivity theory, which states that that the costs of each of the factors of production equalize the factors of marginal productivity.He also argued that efficient distribution of resources does not imply equal distribution, since the distribution of incomes carried out in advance presupposes a form of distribution of resources, and the distribution of income is not always fair.The Stockholm School of Economics developed on the ideas of Wicksell, his quantitative and price theories.

Irving Fisher belonged to the early American neoclassicists of non-standard mathematical methods.His contribution to the "neoclassical" or "marginalist revolution" is extremely important.This Yale economist was an eccentric and colorful personality.When Fischer was writing his dissertation in 1892, he built an interesting machine with pumps, wheels, levers, and pipes to illustrate his price theory.Publicly, he was a supporter of eugenics and healthy diets.He made a fortune on the rolodex card system and supported the idea of ??a 100% reserve bank claims system.His financial position and reputation suffered during the financial crisis of 1929, when, just days before the crisis, he convinced investors that stocks were not overvalued, but had reached a new permanent level.

After a quick defense of his doctoral dissertation, Schumpeter took up jurisprudence without committing himself to a permanent job.While teaching in Chernivtsi (today it is Ukraine), he wrote his "Theory of Economic Development" (1911), where he first developed the famous idea of ??entrepreneurship.He contrasted entrepreneurial courage and technical and financial innovation with falling incomes and competition, and it was these factors, in his opinion, that determined the growth of the economy.In 1919 he became Austrian finance minister, but due to hyperinflation he was removed from his post just a year later.Although he was best able to teach: he was engaged in science and while working at Harvard wrote three more books: "Business Cycles" (1939), "Capitalism, Socialism and Democracy" (1942), in which he predicted the end of capitalism under the leadership of the intelligentsia.

B?hm-Bawerk's scientific career was leaps and bounds.The most significant period in his scientific career was work at the University of Innsbruck (1881-1889).In the 1880s.he published the first two of three volumes of his book Capital and Income.In subsequent years, up to the 1890s.he served as Austrian Minister of Finance, for which he was awarded a portrait on a one hundred schilling banknote.After completing his political career in 1904, he returned to teaching.After teaching a chair at the University of Vienna, he became close to Wieser, a follower of the retired Menger.Among the students who attended the university under B?hm-Bawerk in the last decade of his career (and life: he died in 1914) were Joseph Schumpeter and Ludwig von Mises.

This English economist challenged traditional views on the role of the state in managing the economy and on the relationship between supply and demand during crises.Based on the ability of states to mobilize their economies during war, Keynes argued that the state can effectively influence the economy in peacetime.However, his main contribution to science was the theory of the role of aggregate demand.He believed that it is demand, not supply, that is the key factor affecting the state and growth of the economy and production, and during a recession or crisis, it is necessary to revive demand, which will absorb the surplus of goods and create favorable conditions for the recovery and further increase in production.His theory was subjected to fierce criticism, but little by little it won the minds of politicians and economists of the twentieth century.

This English economist in the early 1930s.developed the concept of the cost multiplier effect in the economy.Its essence is that spending on goods and services creates new demand from the suppliers of these primary goods and services.Thus, the increase in demand exceeds the amount of upfront costs.John Maynard Keynes used this discovery in his theory of the role of aggregate demand in the economy.Subsequently, Kahn's ideas were adopted in many states experiencing a crisis phase as a basis for increasing government spending, leading to a revival of demand and a return to the phase of economic growth.

This Austrian economist was an opponent of Keynes, on the basis of whose theories many countries introduced state regulation of the economy in the 1930s.Von Mises believed that an increase in government spending to revive demand is fraught with inflation, an imbalance in market supply and demand, and, as a result, jeopardizes the stable growth of the economy.Von Mises also criticized socialist models in the economy, believing that the absence of market mechanisms for regulating prices inevitably leads to a mismatch between supply and demand for goods.

This Austrian economist was an opponent of Keynes, on the basis of whose theories many countries introduced state regulation of the economy in the 1930s.Hayek saw economic planning as integral features of the socialist and fascist political models that were gaining popularity at the time.Like his teacher Ludwig von Mises, Hayek criticized Keynes's recommendations for crisis periods and believed that this medicine is worse than the disease, since an increase in demand with a lag in supply creates the preconditions for inflation.He rejected the idea of ??central planning because of its inability to match the quantity and quality of the supply of goods and the demand for them.
This area covers the functioning of the market system.The main indicators of the state of the market are the number of market actors and the level of regulation.
The legislation of your country has structured the market in such a way that each industry is represented by many firms of approximately the same size.
Your country's legislation has structured the market in such a way that each industry is represented by several large firms.
Your country's legislation has structured the market in such a way that each industry is controlled by one large company.
This piece of legislation, allowing ownership of a firm without direct responsibility, was the first step towards securing investment from individuals.
This piece of legislation increased the firm's ability to raise capital from citizens and provided private investors with a high possible return at a certain risk.

This piece of legislation secured legal rights to intellectual property and inventions, which encouraged inventors to patent their ideas and sell them to firms that could introduce them into production.

This piece of legislation meant a guarantee that the firm had exclusive rights to manufacture a particular product.This product had a strong position in the market as it was associated with quality, reliability, etc.

This piece of legislation ended the concentration of power in the market.Sometimes a monopolist with too much influence appeared in the industry, which reduced competition and caused a disproportionate rise in prices.
Financial control of the activities of private firms in the financial markets is being introduced.
Control over the activities of private banks is introduced.
This meant that the board members who made long-term strategic decisions were also involved in the routine activities of the firm, which increased the likelihood of making the right decisions.
The introduction of the bankruptcy procedure not only simplified and accelerated the bankruptcy process, but also reduced the risks of creditors.
The introduction of the annual reporting procedure provided market transparency, which was beneficial to both investors and owners of firms.It also made it easier to monitor troubled firms.

After a series of catastrophes that shook the world economy in the first half of the 20th century, some politicians fell under the influence of new theories about the mutual influence of supply and demand during the crisis.The idea that money injected into the economy has a multiplier effect, creates new income, and increases business activity by creating new demand, has given rise to calls for the use of fiscal pumping to increase demand to stimulate economic growth.Some politicians and economists took these ideas as propaganda of socialist principles.However, those strata of the population who bore the brunt of the crises actively welcomed government intervention and its attempts to improve the state of the economy.

With the onset of the 20th century and the growing influence of alternative models of economic development, different from the capitalist system developed in some countries, some politicians did not deny that combining the best of capitalism and a planned economy could bear fruit.As a result, some states began to intervene in certain economic areas, leaving behind the capitalist foundations of the economy.While many radical critics have debated whether these transformations were not enough or too many, the results of creating a mixed economic system in order to increase production and reduce conflicts between social strata were often impressive.

At the beginning of the twentieth century, radical ideological alternatives to liberal democracy were gaining more and more supporters.The restructuring of the economy based on state control was carried out by communist and fascist regimes and often gave impressive results.The decline in unemployment, the increase in industrial production, and the elimination of the base of conflicts between workers and entrepreneurs were hailed as evidence of the superiority of such systems over the free market system.However, the social and economic costs of such experiments were often very high, and resistance to full state control over economic life sometimes had to be suppressed by repressive methods.Little was known about these internal problems in the outside world, and from the outside such societies seemed to be a worthy alternative to capitalism,

At the beginning of the twentieth century, many states aspired to autarky (self-sufficiency, other Greek), which perceived the growing dependence on the global economy as a threat to national independence or the ideology of the ruling regime.To achieve this goal, such countries introduced huge tariffs - protective barriers for foreign goods, encouraged the development of their industries to replace imports, tightly regulated foreign trade and tried to find replacements for important types of raw materials that they had to purchase abroad.Autarchy in the twentieth century can be called in some way a return to the politics of mercantilism.Although the policy of autarchy was mainly pursued by the communist and fascist regimes, which rejected the capitalist model of the economy,

The rapid growth of the world economy in the 19th and early 20th centuries.caused an increase in demand for manufactured goods from states that do not belong to Western civilization.However, during periods of wars between industrial powers and more frequent economic crises, traditional suppliers of such goods were not always able to meet the demand of the rest of the world.As a result, local producers were able to fill the resulting niche, and industrialization began in non-non-Western countries.Due to the need to protect their producers from competition with imports, some states that retained their political independence resorted to the policy of import-substitution industrialization, which was supposed to weaken their dependence on Western goods and strengthen their position in the world economy.
Rapid growth of the world economy in the 19th and early 20th centuries.caused an increase in demand for rubber, the production of which was severely limited
This area includes the internal development of enterprises.The internal rules and style of work have changed over time as economics developed.
The systematization of production has increased productivity and production efficiency.
Labor specialization has increased the speed of work and the competence of workers.
The introduction of a workers' control system and hierarchy, in which professional supervision of production was carried out, increased the efficiency and productivity of enterprises.

The introduction of a system for calculating time and material costs and a production planning system at all stages: from the purchase of raw materials to the sale of the final product has increased the efficiency of production chains.
Planning for the use of goods and equipment has been introduced and support for the activities of funds, the funds of which are used to purchase new equipment to maintain the level of production.
A procedure has been introduced for checking goods for the presence of a single confirmed level of quality.

Applying time analysis to each employee completing a task and analyzing measures to improve productivity, which is achieved either by changing production methods or by sequentially transferring the task to other employees.

The introduction of fixed working hours has increased production efficiency.Workers were now able to work in shifts, which further increased productivity, and the old life of working from dawn to dusk was done away with.This measure also eased social tensions in society.
The introduction of lighting in the workshops of enterprises has increased labor productivity.Workers can now also work night shifts, which will further increase the level of production.

This business style meant that the owners treated it like a family business, such as a store or restaurant.The line between personal and business was blurred.The business practice was very emotional and the business owners took huge risks and lacked professionalism.

This business style meant that the business owners treated it like an investment.Owning an enterprise did not involve the production and sale of goods.The sole purpose of owning a business was to improve the economic performance of the enterprise.This activity was professional, but it lacked financial commitment and initiative.
This business style meant that business owners either started it from scratch or bought it off the shelf.This often implied a conservative but rather successful way of doing business.

This theory of production management, created by Frederick Winslow Taylor in 1911, argued that labor productivity can be maximized by optimizing and correctly distributing operations among highly specialized workers.This idea of ??"adjusting workers to work", combined with giving them breaks to relieve stress from monotonous work activities, formed the basis of a new approach to organizing and expanding production.However, Taylor viewed workers as cogs in the general machinery of production, and some saw the spread of Taylorism as the cause of the growth of the trade union movement and the spread of socialist ideas among the workers.

This theory of production management was developed in the work of Elton Mayo, who studied labor productivity in the Hawthorne factories in Chicago in the 1920s.Unlike Taylor, Mayo, based on his data, suggested paying more attention to the human factor in increasing labor productivity.He believed that it was necessary to make workers feel like an important part of the production process, and not just cogs in a machine.Mayo's arguments have been refuted by many researchers, but his theory has found many supporters.
Aesthetics encompasses the development and improvement of literature, art and music.

The adherents of romanticism finally broke with the requirements of the rigor and correctness of classicism.By glorifying and exploring human emotions and imagination, they laid the foundation for future cultural movements in the 19th and 20th centuries.Romanticists included William Wordsworth, Samuel Taylor Coleridge, Lord Byron, Percy Bysshe Shelley, and John Keats.

The adherents of romanticism finally broke with the requirements of the rigor and correctness of classicism.By glorifying and exploring human emotions and imagination, they laid the foundation for future cultural movements in the 19th and 20th centuries.Among the great romanticist artists were J.M.W.Turner, Caspar David Frederick, John Constable, William Blake.

The adherents of romanticism finally abandoned the strictness and correctness traditional for the music of that time.They did not hesitate to show and celebrate human emotions and feelings, laying the foundation for the cultural trends of the 19th and 20th centuries.The most prominent composers of the Romantic era were Ludwig van Beethoven, Friedrich Chopin and Franz Schubert.

Realists opposed the idealization of life inherent in their contemporary culture.They saw their goal in depicting life as it really is.The attention of realists was often riveted to the small details of the lives of ordinary people.

Realists opposed the idealization of life inherent in their contemporary culture.They saw their goal in depicting life as it really is.The attention of realists was often riveted to the small details in the lives of ordinary people.

Realists opposed the idealization of life inherent in their contemporary culture.They saw their goal in depicting life as it really is.The attention of realists was often riveted to the small details of the lives of ordinary people.

The Impressionists sought to depict the world not as they see it and as it really is, but as they feel it and how it can be.To express themselves, they had to significantly expand the arsenal of available artistic means.In literature, the Impressionists usually turned to symbolism, describing feelings in a very vague and unclear way.Among the Impressionist writers and poets, the best known are Paul Verlaine, Stephen Mallarm?, the Americans T.E.Elliot and James Joyce.

The Impressionists sought to depict the world not as they see it and as it really is, but as they feel it and how it can be.To express themselves, they had to significantly expand the arsenal of available artistic means.Among the artists whose contribution to world culture is especially great are the impressionists Claude Monet, Auguste Renoir, Alfred Sisley and Fred Basil.

The Impressionists sought to depict the world not as they see it and as it really is, but as they feel it and how it can be.To express themselves, they had to significantly expand the arsenal of available artistic means.The forerunner of Impressionist music was Claude Debussy, and the main impressionist composers were Maurice Ravel, Frederic Delius and Ottorino Respighi, whose music became a rebellion against the ideals of romanticism that dominated for many years.
Expressionists paid special attention to the depiction of human emotions, soul, inner world.

Expressionists paid special attention to the depiction of human emotions, soul, inner world.The most famous expressionist painters were representatives of the German school Ernst Ludwig Kirchner, Erich Heckel, EmilNolde, Max Pechstein and Otto M?ller.

Expressionists paid special attention to the depiction of human emotions, soul, inner world.Expressionist composers Schoenberg, Alban Berg and Paul Hindemith made a real revolution in music, abandoning the integrity of the composition and the unity of the musical theme.

Using completely new means of artistic depiction, avant-garde artists finally destroyed the foundations of traditional culture.However, despite the popularity of this trend, only a few of its representatives were able to become recognized masters.

Using completely new means of artistic depiction, avant-garde artists finally destroyed the foundations of traditional culture.However, despite the popularity of this trend, only a few of its representatives were able to become recognized masters.

Using completely new means of artistic depiction, avant-garde artists finally destroyed the foundations of traditional culture.However, despite the popularity of this trend, only a few of its representatives were able to become recognized masters.

Developing from Dadaism filled with iconoclasm, surrealism tries to lure the reader or viewer into a journey through the world of inner images created by human consciousness, where, from his point of view, only true reality exists.In essence, this is an invitation to escape from the horrors of modern war and the corrosive commercialism of society.The term itself was coined by Andr? Burton.The most prominent representative of this trend is Salvador Dali.
